Chapter 1.Header: Genealogy from Abraham until the coming of Christ
Chapter 1.1: The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the Son of David, the son of Abraham.
Chapter 1.2: Abraham begat Isaac; and Isaac begat Jacob; and Jacob begat Judas and his brethren; and Judas begat Phares and Zara of Thamar; and Phares begat Esrom; and Esrom begat Aram; and Aram begat Aminadab; and Aminadab begat Naason; and Naason begat Salmon; and Salmon begat Booz of Rachab; and Booz begat Obed of Ruth; and Obed begat Jesse; and Jesse begat David the king.
Chapter 1.3: And David the king begat Solomon of her whom David had taken of Urias; and Solomon begat Roboam; and Roboam begat Abia; and Abia begat Asa; and Asa begat Josaphat; and Josaphat begat Joram; and Joram begat Ozias; and Ozias begat Joatham; and Joatham begat Achaz; and Achaz begat Ezekias; and Ezekias begat Manasses; and Manasses begat Amon; and Amon begat Josias; and Josias begat Jechonias and his brethren, about the time they were carried away to Babylon.
Chapter 1.4: And after they were brought to Babylon, Jechonias begat Salathiel; and Salathiel begat Zorobable; and Zorobable begat Abiud; and Abiud begat Eliakim; and Eliakim begat Azor; and Azor begat Sadoc; and Sadoc begat Achim; and Achim begat Eliud; and Eliud begat Eleazar; and Eleazar begat ; and  begat Jacob; and Jacob begat Joseph, the husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus, as the prophets have written, who is called Christ.
Chapter 1.5: So all the generations from Abraham to David were fourteen generations; and from David until the carrying away into Babylon were fourteen generations; and from the carrying away into Babylon until Christ were fourteen generations.

Chapter 2.1: Now, as it is written, the birth of Jesus Christ was on this wise. After his mother, Mary, was espoused to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Ghost.
Chapter 2.2: Then Joseph, her husband, being a just man and not willing to make her a public example, was minded to put her away privily.
Chapter 2.3: But while he thought on these things, behold, the angel of the Lord appeared unto him in a vision, saying, Joseph, thou son of David, fear not to take unto thee Mary thy wife; for that which is conceived in her is of the Holy Ghost.
Chapter 2.4: And she shall bring forth a son, and thou shalt call his name Jesus; for he shall save his people from their sins.
Chapter 2.5: Now this took place that all things might be fulfilled which were spoken of the Lord by the prophets, saying,
Chapter 2.6: Behold, a virgin shall be with child and shall bring forth a son, and they shall call his name Emmanuel (which, being interpreted, is God with us).
Chapter 2.7: Then Joseph, awaking out of his vision, did as the angel of the Lord had bidden him, and took unto him his wife,
Chapter 2.8: And knew her not until she had brought forth her firstborn son; and they called his name Jesus.

Chapter 3.Header: Joseph flees to Egypt--John's mission--Baptism of Jesus
Chapter 3.1: Now when Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea, in the days of Herod the king, behold, there came wise men from the east to Jerusalem,
Chapter 3.2: Saying, Where is the child that is born, the Messiah of the Jews? For we have seen his star in the east and have come to worship him.
Chapter 3.3: When Herod the king had heard of the child, he was troubled, and all Jerusalem with him.
Chapter 3.4: And when he had gathered all the chief priests and scribes of the people together, he demanded of them, saying, Where is the place that is written of by the prophets, in which Christ should be born? For he greatly feared, yet he believed not the prophets.
Chapter 3.5: And they said unto him, It is written by the prophets that he should be born in Bethlehem of Judea, for thus have they said,
Chapter 3.6: The word of the Lord came unto us, saying, And thou Bethlehem, which lieth in the land of Judea, in thee shall be born a prince, which art not the least among the princes of Judea; for out of thee shall come the Messiah, who shall save my people Israel.
Chapter 3.7: Then Herod, when he had called the wise men privily, inquired of them diligently at what time the star appeared.
Chapter 3.8: And he sent them to Bethlehem and said, Go and search diligently for the young child; and when ye have found the child, bring me word again, that I may come and worship him also.
Chapter 3.9: When they had heard the king, they departed; and lo, the star which they saw in the east went before them until it came and stood over where the young child was.
Chapter 3.10: When they saw the star, they rejoiced with exceeding great joy.
Chapter 3.11: And when they were come into the house, they saw the young child, with Mary his mother, and fell down and worshiped him. And when they had opened their treasures, they presented unto him gifts: gold, and frankincense, and myrrh.
Chapter 3.12: And being warned of God in a dream that they should not return to Herod, they departed into their own country another way.
Chapter 3.13: And when they were departed, behold, the angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a vision, saying, Arise, and take the young child and his mother, and flee into Egypt, and tarry thou there until I bring thee word; for Herod will seek the young child to destroy him.
Chapter 3.14: And then he arose, and took the young child and the child's mother by night, and departed into Egypt,
Chapter 3.15: And was there until the death of Herod, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken of the Lord by the prophet, saying, Out of Egypt have I called my Son.
Chapter 3.16: Then Herod, when he saw that he was mocked of the wise men, was exceeding wroth, and sent forth, and slew all the children that were in Bethlehem and all the coasts thereof, from two years old and under, according to the time which he had diligently inquired of the wise men.
Chapter 3.17: Then was fulfilled that which was spoken by Jeremiah the prophet, saying,
Chapter 3.18: In Ramah there was a voice heard: lamentation, and weeping, and great mourning--Rachael weeping for the loss of her children, and would not be comforted because they were not.
Chapter 3.19: But when Herod was dead, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared in a vision to Joseph in Egypt,
Chapter 3.20: Saying, Arise, and take the young child and his mother, and go into the land of Israel; for they are dead who sought the young child's life.
Chapter 3.21: And he arose, and took the young child and his mother, and came into the land of Israel.
Chapter 3.22: But when he heard that Archelaus did reign in Judea in the stead of his father Herod, he was afraid to go thither; but, notwithstanding, being warned of God in a vision, he went into the eastern part of Galilee;
Chapter 3.23: And he came and dwelt in a city called Nazareth, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophets, He shall be called a Nazarene.
Chapter 3.24: And it came to pass that Jesus grew up with his brethren, and waxed strong, and waited upon the Lord for the time of his ministry to come.
Chapter 3.25: And he served under his father, and he spake not as other men, neither could he be taught; for he needed not that any man should teach him.
Chapter 3.26: And after many years, the hour of his ministry drew nigh.
Chapter 3.27: And in those days came John the Baptist, preaching in the wilderness of Judea,
Chapter 3.28: And saying, Repent ye, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.
Chapter 3.29: For I am he who was spoken of by the prophet Esaias, saying, The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord and make his paths straight.
Chapter 3.30: And the same John had his raiment of camels' hair and a leathern girdle about his loins; and his food was locusts and wild honey.
Chapter 3.31: Then went out to him Jerusalem, and all Judea, and all the region round about Jordan,
Chapter 3.32: And many were baptized of him in Jordan, confessing their sins.
Chapter 3.33: But when he saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees come to his baptism, he said unto them, O, generation of vipers! Who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come?
Chapter 3.34: Why is it that ye receive not the preaching of him whom God hath sent? If ye receive not this in your hearts, ye receive not me; and if ye receive not me, ye receive not him of whom I am sent to bear record; and for your sins ye have no cloak.
Chapter 3.35: Repent, therefore, and bring forth fruits meet for repentance;
Chapter 3.36: And think not to say within yourselves, We are the children of Abraham, and we only have power to bring seed unto our father Abraham; for I say unto you that God is able of these stones to raise up children unto Abraham.
Chapter 3.37: And now, also, the axe is laid unto the root of the trees; therefore, every tree which bringeth not forth good fruit shall be hewn down and cast into the fire.
Chapter 3.38: I indeed baptize you with water, upon your repentance; and when he of whom I bear record cometh, who is mightier than I, whose shoes I am not worthy to bear (or whose place I am not able to fill), as I said, I indeed baptize you before he cometh, that when he cometh, he may baptize you with the Holy Ghost and fire.
Chapter 3.39: And it is he of whom I shall bear record, whose fan shall be in his hand; and he will thoroughly purge his floor, and gather his wheat into the garner, but in the fullness of his own time will burn up the chaff with unquenchable fire.
Chapter 3.40: Thus came John, preaching and baptizing in the river of Jordan, bearing record that he who was coming after him had power to baptize with the Holy Ghost and fire.
Chapter 3.41: And then cometh Jesus from Galilee to Jordan unto John to be baptized of him;
Chapter 3.42: But John refused him, saying, I have need to be baptized of thee. And why comest thou to me?
Chapter 3.43: And Jesus, answering, said unto him, Suffer me to be baptized of thee, for thus it becometh us to fulfill all righteousness. Then he suffered him.
Chapter 3.44: And John went down into the water and baptized him.
Chapter 3.45: And Jesus, when he was baptized, went up straightway out of the water; and John saw, and lo, the heavens were opened unto him; and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and lighting upon Jesus.
Chapter 3.46: And lo, he heard a voice from heaven saying, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased. Hear ye him.

Chapter 4.Header: Christ led away by the Spirit--Tempted of the devil--Commencement of Christ's ministry
Chapter 4.1: Then Jesus was led up of the Spirit into the wilderness to be with God.
Chapter 4.2: And when he had fasted forty days and forty nights and had communed with God, he was afterwards an hungered and was left to be tempted of the devil.
Chapter 4.3: And when the tempter came to him, he said, If thou be the Son of God, command that these stones be made bread.
Chapter 4.4: But Jesus answered and said, It is written, Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God.
Chapter 4.5: Then Jesus was taken up into the holy city, and the Spirit setteth him on the pinnacle of the temple.
Chapter 4.6: Then the devil came unto him and said, If thou be the Son of God, cast thyself down; for it is written, He shall give his angels charge concerning thee, and in their hands they shall bear thee up, lest at any time thou dash thy foot against a stone.
Chapter 4.7: Jesus said unto him, It is written again, Thou shalt not tempt the Lord, thy God.
Chapter 4.8: And again, Jesus was in the Spirit; and it taketh him up into an exceeding high mountain and showeth him all the kingdoms of the world and the glory of them.
Chapter 4.9: And the devil came unto him again and said, All these things will I give unto thee, if thou wilt fall down and worship me.
Chapter 4.10: Then said Jesus unto him, Get thee hence, Satan; for it is written, Thou shalt worship the Lord, thy God, and him only shalt thou serve. Then the devil leaveth him.
Chapter 4.11: And now Jesus knew that John was cast into prison; and he sent angels, and behold, they came and ministered unto him.
Chapter 4.12: And Jesus departed into Galilee; and leaving Nazareth in Zebulun, he came and dwelt in Capernaum, which is upon the seacoast in the borders of Nephthalim,
Chapter 4.13: That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying,
Chapter 4.14: The land of Zebulun and the land of Nephthalim, in the way of the sea beyond Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles;
Chapter 4.15: The people which sat in darkness saw a great light; and unto them that sat in the region and shadow of death, light is sprung up.
Chapter 4.16: From that time, Jesus began to preach and to say, Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.
Chapter 4.17: And Jesus, walking by the sea of Galilee, saw two brethren, Simon, called Peter, and Andrew, his brother, casting a net into the sea, for they were fishers.
Chapter 4.18: And he said unto them, I am he of whom it is written by the prophets. Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men.
Chapter 4.19: And they, believing on his words, left their nets and straightway followed him.
Chapter 4.20: And going on from thence, he saw two other brethren, James and John, his brother, the sons of Zebedee, in a ship with Zebedee, their father, mending their nets; and he called them.
Chapter 4.21: And they immediately left their father in the ship and followed him.
Chapter 4.22: And Jesus went about all Galilee teaching in their synagogues, and preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing all manner of sickness and all manner of diseases among the people which believed on his name.
Chapter 4.23: And his fame went throughout all Syria; and they brought unto him all sick people that were taken with divers diseases, and torments, and those who were possessed with devils, and those who were lunatic, and those that had the palsy; and he healed them.
Chapter 4.24: And there followed him great multitudes of people from Galilee, and Decapolis, and Jerusalem, and Judea, and beyond Jordan.

Chapter 5.1: And Jesus, seeing the multitudes, went up into a mountain; and when he was set down, his disciples came unto him;
Chapter 5.2: And he opened his mouth and taught them, saying,
Chapter 5.3: Blessed are they who shall believe on me; and again, more blessed are they who shall believe on your words when ye shall testify that ye have seen me and that I am.
Chapter 5.4: Yea, blessed are they who shall believe on your words, and come down into the depth of humility, and be baptized in my name; for they shall be visited with fire and the Holy Ghost and shall receive a remission of their sins.
Chapter 5.5: Yea, blessed are the poor in spirit who come unto me; for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
Chapter 5.6: And again, blessed are they that mourn; for they shall be comforted.
Chapter 5.7: And blessed are the meek; for they shall inherit the earth.
Chapter 5.8: And blessed are all they that do hunger and thirst after righteousness; for they shall be filled with the Holy Ghost.
Chapter 5.9: And blessed are the merciful; for they shall obtain mercy.
Chapter 5.10: And blessed are all the pure in heart; for they shall see God.
Chapter 5.11: And blessed are all the peacemakers; for they shall be called the children of God.
Chapter 5.12: Blessed are all they that are persecuted for my name's sake; for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
Chapter 5.13: And blessed are ye when men shall revile you, and persecute you, and shall say all manner of evil against you falsely, for my sake;
Chapter 5.14: For ye shall have great joy and be exceeding glad; for great shall be your reward in heaven; for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.
Chapter 5.15: Verily, verily, I say unto you, I give unto you to be the salt of the earth; but if the salt shall lose its savor, wherewith shall the earth be salted? The salt shall thenceforth be good for nothing, but to be cast out and to be trodden underfoot of men.
Chapter 5.16: Verily, verily, I say unto you, I give unto you to be the light of the world; a city that is set on a hill cannot be hid.
Chapter 5.17: Behold, do men light a candle and put it under a bushel? Nay, but on a candlestick; and it giveth light to all that are in the house.
Chapter 5.18: Therefore, let your light so shine before this world, that they may see your good works and glorify your Father who is in heaven.
Chapter 5.19: Think not that I am come to destroy the law or the prophets; I am not come to destroy, but to fulfill.
Chapter 5.20: For verily, I say unto you, Heaven and earth must pass away, but one jot or one tittle shall in no wise pass from the law until all be fulfilled.
Chapter 5.21: Whosoever, therefore, shall break one of these least commandments and shall teach men so to do, he shall in no wise be saved in the kingdom of heaven; but whosoever shall do and teach these commandments of the law until it be fulfilled, the same shall be called great and shall be saved in the kingdom of heaven.
Chapter 5.22: For I say unto you, except your righteousness shall exceed that of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven.
Chapter 5.23: Ye have heard that it hath been said by them of old time that thou shalt not kill; and whosoever shall kill shall be in danger of the judgment of God.
Chapter 5.24: But I say unto you that whosoever is angry with his brother shall be in danger of his judgment; and whosoever shall say to his brother, Raca, or Rabcha, shall be in danger of the council; and whosoever shall say to his brother, Thou fool, shall be in danger of hellfire.
Chapter 5.25: Therefore, if ye shall come unto me, or shall desire to come unto me, or if thou bring thy gift to the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother hath aught against thee,
Chapter 5.26: Leave thou thy gift before the altar, and go thy way unto thy brother, and first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift.
Chapter 5.27: Agree with thine adversary quickly, while thou art in the way with him, lest at any time thine adversary deliver thee to the judge, and the judge deliver thee to the officer, and thou be cast into prison.
Chapter 5.28: Verily, I say unto thee, Thou shalt by no means come out thence until thou hast paid the uttermost farthing.
Chapter 5.29: Behold, it is written by them of old time that thou shalt not commit adultery.
Chapter 5.30: But I say unto you that whosoever looketh on a woman, to lust after her, hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.
Chapter 5.31: Behold, I give unto you a commandment, that ye suffer none of these things to enter into your heart; for it is better that ye should deny yourselves of these things, wherein ye will take up your cross, than that ye should be cast into hell.
Chapter 5.32: Therefore, if thy right eye offend thee, pluck it out and cast it from thee; for it is profitable for thee that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into hell.
Chapter 5.33: Or if thy right hand offend thee, cut it off and cast it from thee; for it is profitable for thee that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into hell.
Chapter 5.34: And now this I speak, a parable concerning your sins; wherefore, cast them from you, that ye may not be hewn down and cast into the fire.
Chapter 5.35: It hath been written that whosoever shall put away his wife, let him give her a writing of divorcement.
Chapter 5.36: Verily, verily, I say unto you that whosoever shall put away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to commit adultery; and whosoever shall marry her that is divorced committeth adultery.
Chapter 5.37: Again, it hath been written by them of old time, Thou shalt not forswear thyself, but shalt perform unto the Lord thine oaths.
Chapter 5.38: But I say unto you, Swear not at all: neither by heaven, for it is God's throne; nor by the earth, for it is his footstool; neither by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King; neither shalt thou swear by thy head, because thou canst not make one hair white or black.
Chapter 5.39: But let your communication be Yea, yea; Nay, nay; for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil.
Chapter 5.40: Ye have heard that it hath been said, An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth.
Chapter 5.41: But I say unto you that ye resist not evil; but whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other also.
Chapter 5.42: And if any man will sue thee at the law and take away thy coat, let him have it; and if he sue thee again, let him have thy cloak also.
Chapter 5.43: And whosoever shall compel thee to go a mile, go with him a mile; and whosoever shall compel thee to go with him twain, thou shalt go with him twain.
Chapter 5.44: Give to him that asketh of thee; and from him that would borrow of thee, turn not thou away.
Chapter 5.45: Ye have heard that it hath been said, Thou shalt love thy neighbor, and hate thine enemy.
Chapter 5.46: But I say unto you, Love your enemies; bless them that curse you; do good to them that hate you; and pray for them which despitefully use you and persecute you;
Chapter 5.47: That ye may be the children of your Father who is in heaven; for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust.
Chapter 5.48: For if ye love only them which love you, what reward have you? Do not even the publicans the same?
Chapter 5.49: And if ye salute your brethren only, what do ye more than others? Do not even the publicans the same?
Chapter 5.50: Ye are, therefore, commanded to be perfect, even as your Father who is in heaven is perfect.

Chapter 6.Header: Christ's teaching on the mount continued
Chapter 6.1: And it came to pass that as Jesus taught his disciples, he said unto them, Take heed that ye do not your alms before men to be seen of them; otherwise, ye have no reward of your Father who is in heaven.
Chapter 6.2: Therefore, when thou doest alms, do not sound a trumpet before thee as the hypocrites do in the synagogues and in the streets, that they may have glory of men. Verily, I say unto you, They have their reward.
Chapter 6.3: But when thou doest alms, let it be unto thee as thy left hand not knowing what thy right hand doeth,
Chapter 6.4: That thine alms may be in secret; and thy Father who seeth in secret, himself shall reward thee openly.
Chapter 6.5: And when thou prayest, thou shalt not be as the hypocrites; for they love to pray standing in the synagogues and in the corners of the streets, that they may be seen of men; for, verily, I say unto you, They have their reward.
Chapter 6.6: But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet; and when thou hast shut the door, pray to thy Father who is in secret; and thy Father who seeth in secret shall reward thee openly.
Chapter 6.7: But when ye pray, use not vain repetitions as the hypocrites do; for they think that they shall be heard for their much speaking.
Chapter 6.8: Therefore, be ye not like unto them; for your Father knoweth what things ye have need of before ye ask him.
Chapter 6.9: Therefore, after this manner shall ye pray, saying,
Chapter 6.10: Our Father who art in heaven, Hallowed be thy name.
Chapter 6.11: Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done on earth, as it is done in heaven.
Chapter 6.12: Give us this day our daily bread.
Chapter 6.13: And forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive those who trespass against us.
Chapter 6.14: And suffer us not to be led into temptation, but deliver us from evil.
Chapter 6.15: For thine is the kingdom, and the power, and the glory, forever and ever, Amen.
Chapter 6.16: For if ye forgive men their trespasses, who trespass against you, your heavenly Father will also forgive you; but if ye forgive not men their trespasses, neither will your heavenly Father forgive you your trespasses.
Chapter 6.17: Moreover, when ye fast, be not as the hypocrites, of a sad countenance; for they disfigure their faces, that they may appear unto men to fast. Verily, I say unto you, They have their reward.
Chapter 6.18: But thou, when thou fastest, anoint thy head and wash thy face, that thou appear not unto men to fast, but unto thy Father who is in secret; and thy Father who seeth in secret shall reward thee openly.
Chapter 6.19: Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth corrupt and where thieves break through and steal.
Chapter 6.20: But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt and where thieves do not break through nor steal.
Chapter 6.21: For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.
Chapter 6.22: The light of the body is the eye; if, therefore, thine eye be single to the glory of God, thy whole body shall be full of light.
Chapter 6.23: But if thine eye be evil, thy whole body shall be full of darkness. If, therefore, the light which is in thee be darkness, how great shall that darkness be.
Chapter 6.24: No man can serve two masters; for either he will hate the one and love the other, or else he will hold to the one and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon.
Chapter 6.25: And again, I say unto you, Go ye into the world and care not for the world; for the world will hate you, and will persecute you, and will turn you out of their synagogues.
Chapter 6.26: Nevertheless, ye shall go forth from house to house, teaching the people; and I will go before you.
Chapter 6.27: And your heavenly Father will provide for you whatsoever things ye need for food, what ye shall eat, and for raiment, what ye shall wear or put on.
Chapter 6.28: Therefore, I say unto you, Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat or what ye shall drink, nor yet for your bodies, what ye shall put on. Is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment?
Chapter 6.29: Behold the fowls of the air, for they sow not; neither do they reap, nor gather into barns; yet your heavenly Father feedeth them. Are ye not much better than they? How much more will he not feed you?
Chapter 6.30: Wherefore, take no thought for these things, but keep my commandments wherewith I have commanded you.
Chapter 6.31: For which of you by taking thought can add one cubit unto his stature?
Chapter 6.32: And why take ye thought for raiment? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow; they toil not, neither do they spin.
Chapter 6.33: And yet I say unto you that even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these.
Chapter 6.34: Therefore, if God so clothe the grass of the field, which today is, and tomorrow is cast into the oven, how much more will he not provide for you if ye are not of little faith.
Chapter 6.35: Therefore, take no thought, saying, What shall we eat? or, What shall we drink? or, Wherewithal shall we be clothed?
Chapter 6.36: Why is it that ye murmur among yourselves, saying, We cannot obey thy word, because ye have not all these things, and seek to excuse yourselves, saying that after all these things do the Gentiles seek.
Chapter 6.37: Behold, I say unto you that your heavenly Father knoweth that ye have need of all these things.
Chapter 6.38: Wherefore, seek not the things of this world; but seek ye first to build up the kingdom of God and to establish his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
Chapter 6.39: Take, therefore, no thought for the morrow; for the morrow shall take thought for the things of itself. Sufficient unto the day shall be the evil thereof.

Chapter 7.Header: Christ instructs his disciples what to teach unto the world
Chapter 7.1: Now these are the words which Jesus taught his disciples that they should say unto the people:
Chapter 7.2: Judge not unrighteously, that ye be not judged; but judge righteous judgment.
Chapter 7.3: For with what judgment ye shall judge, ye shall be judged; and with what measure ye mete, it shall be measured to you again.
Chapter 7.4: And again, ye shall say unto them, Why is it that thou beholdest the mote that is in thy brother's eye, but considerest not the beam that is in thine own eye?
Chapter 7.5: Or how wilt thou say to thy brother, Let me pull out the mote out of thine eye, and canst not behold a beam in thine own eye?
Chapter 7.6: And Jesus said unto his disciples, Beholdest thou the scribes, and the Pharisees, and the priests, and the Levites? They teach in their synagogues, but do not observe the law nor the commandments; and all have gone out of the way and are under sin.
Chapter 7.7: Go thou and say unto them, Why teach ye men the law and the commandments, when ye yourselves are the children of corruption?
Chapter 7.8: Say unto them, Ye hypocrites! First cast out the beam out of thine own eye; and then shalt thou see clearly to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye.
Chapter 7.9: Go ye into the world, saying unto all, Repent, for the kingdom of heaven has come nigh unto you.
Chapter 7.10: And the mysteries of the kingdom ye shall keep within yourselves; for it is not meet to give that which is holy unto the dogs; neither cast ye your pearls unto swine, lest they trample them under their feet.
Chapter 7.11: For the world cannot receive that which ye, yourselves, are not able to bear; wherefore, ye shall not give your pearls unto them, lest they turn again and rend you.
Chapter 7.12: Say unto them, Ask of God; ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you.
Chapter 7.13: For everyone that asketh, receiveth; and he that seeketh, findeth; and unto him that knocketh, it shall be opened.
Chapter 7.14: And then said his disciples unto him, They will say unto us, We ourselves are righteous and need not that any man should teach us. God, we know, heard Moses and some of the prophets; but us he will not hear.
Chapter 7.15: And they will say, We have the law for our salvation, and that is sufficient for us.
Chapter 7.16: Then Jesus answered and said unto his disciples, Thus shall ye say unto them:
Chapter 7.17: What man among you, having a son, and he shall be standing out and shall say, Father, open thy house that I may come in and sup with thee, will not say, Come in, my son; for mine is thine, and thine is mine?
Chapter 7.18: Or what man is there among you, who, if his son ask bread, will give him a stone?
Chapter 7.19: Or if he ask a fish, will he give him a serpent?
Chapter 7.20: If ye then, being evil, know how to give good gifts unto your children, how much more shall your Father who is in heaven give good things to them that ask him?
Chapter 7.21: Therefore, all things whatsoever ye would that men should do to you, do ye even so to them; for this is the law and the prophets.
Chapter 7.22: Repent, therefore, and enter ye in at the strait gate; for wide is the gate and broad is the way that leadeth to destruction; and many there be who go in thereat.
Chapter 7.23: Because strait is the gate and narrow is the way that leadeth unto life; and few there be that find it.
Chapter 7.24: And again, beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheep's clothing, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.
Chapter 7.25: Ye shall know them by their fruits; for do men gather grapes of thorns or figs of thistles?
Chapter 7.26: Even so, every good tree bringeth forth good fruit; but a corrupt tree bringeth forth evil fruit.
Chapter 7.27: A good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit; neither can a corrupt tree bring forth good fruit.
Chapter 7.28: Every tree that bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down and cast into the fire.
Chapter 7.29: Wherefore, by their fruits ye shall know them.
Chapter 7.30: Verily, I say unto you, It is not everyone that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, that shall enter into the kingdom of heaven, but he that doeth the will of my Father who is in heaven.
Chapter 7.31: For the day soon cometh that men shall come before me to judgment, to be judged according to their works.
Chapter 7.32: And many will say unto me in that day, Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in thy name; and in thy name cast out devils; and in thy name done many wonderful works?
Chapter 7.33: And then will I say, Ye never knew me; depart from me, ye that work iniquity.
Chapter 7.34: Therefore, whosoever heareth these sayings of mine and doeth them, I will liken him unto a wise man, who built his house upon a rock; and the rains descended, and the floods came, and the winds blew and beat upon that house; and it fell not, for it was founded upon a rock.
Chapter 7.35: And everyone that heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them not, shall be likened unto a foolish man, who built his house upon the sand; and the rains descended, and the floods came, and the winds blew and beat upon that house; and it fell, and great was the fall of it.
Chapter 7.36: And it came to pass when Jesus had ended these sayings with his disciples, the people were astonished at his doctrine;
Chapter 7.37: For he taught them as one having authority from God, and not as having authority from the scribes.

Chapter 8.Header: Jesus comes down from the mountain--Does many mighty works--Sends devils into swine
Chapter 8.1: And when Jesus was come down from the mountain, great multitudes followed him.
Chapter 8.2: And, behold, there came a leper worshiping him, saying, Lord, if thou wilt, thou canst make me clean.
Chapter 8.3: And Jesus put forth his hand and touched him, saying, I will; be thou clean. And immediately his leprosy was cleansed.
Chapter 8.4: And Jesus said unto him, See thou tell no man; but go thy way, and show thyself to the priest, and offer the gift that Moses commanded, for a testimony unto them.
Chapter 8.5: And when Jesus was entered into Capernaum, there came unto him a centurion, beseeching him and saying, Lord, my servant lieth at home sick of the palsy, grievously tormented.
Chapter 8.6: And Jesus said unto him, I will come and heal him.
Chapter 8.7: The centurion answered and said, Lord, I am not worthy that thou shouldest come under my roof; but speak the word only, and my servant shall be healed.
Chapter 8.8: For I am a man under authority, having soldiers under me; and I say to this man, Go, and he goeth; and to another, Come, and he cometh; and to my servant, Do this, and he doeth it.
Chapter 8.9: And when they that followed him heard this, they marveled. And when Jesus heard this, he said unto them that followed,
Chapter 8.10: Verily, I say unto you, I have not found so great faith; no, not in Israel.
Chapter 8.11: And I say unto you that many shall come from the east and the west, and shall sit down with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob in the kingdom of heaven.
Chapter 8.12: But the children of the wicked one shall be cast out into outer darkness; there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Chapter 8.13: And Jesus said unto the centurion, Go thy way; and as thou hast believed, so be it done unto thee. And his servant was healed in the selfsame hour.
Chapter 8.14: And when Jesus was come into Peter's house, he saw his wife's mother laid and sick of a fever.
Chapter 8.15: And he touched her hand, and the fever left her; and she arose and ministered unto them.
Chapter 8.16: Now when the evening was come, they brought unto him many that were possessed with devils; and he cast out the evil spirits with the word and healed all that were sick,
Chapter 8.17: That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying, Himself took our infirmities and bare our sicknesses.
Chapter 8.18: Now when Jesus saw great multitudes about him, he gave commandment to depart unto the other side of the sea.
Chapter 8.19: And a certain scribe came unto him and said, Master, I will follow thee whithersoever thou goest.
Chapter 8.20: And Jesus said unto him, The foxes have holes, and the birds of the air have nests; but the Son of Man hath not where to lay his head.
Chapter 8.21: And another of his disciples said unto him, Lord, suffer me first to go and bury my father.
Chapter 8.22: But Jesus said unto him, Follow me, and let the dead bury their dead.
Chapter 8.23: And when he was entered into a ship, his disciples came unto him.
Chapter 8.24: And, behold, there arose a great tempest in the sea, insomuch that the ship was covered with the waves; but he was asleep.
Chapter 8.25: And his disciples came unto him and awoke him, saying, Lord, save us, else we perish.
Chapter 8.26: And he said unto them, Why are ye fearful, O ye of little faith?
Chapter 8.27: Then he arose and rebuked the winds and the sea; and there was a great calm.
Chapter 8.28: But the men marveled, saying, What manner of man is this, that even the winds and the sea obey him?
Chapter 8.29: And when he was come to the other side, into the country of the Gergesenes, there met him a man possessed of devils, coming out of the tombs, exceeding fierce, so that no man could pass that way.
Chapter 8.30: And, behold, he cried out, saying, What have we to do with thee, Jesus, thou Son of God? Art thou come hither to torment us before the time?
Chapter 8.31: And there was, a good way off from them, a herd of many swine feeding.
Chapter 8.32: So the devils besought him, saying, If thou cast us out, suffer us to go into the herd of swine.
Chapter 8.33: And he said unto them, Go. And when they were come out, they went into the herd of swine; and, behold, the whole herd of swine ran violently down a steep place into the sea and perished in the waters.
Chapter 8.34: And they that kept them fled, and went their way into the city, and told everything which took place and what was befallen the possessed of the devils.
Chapter 8.35: And, behold, the whole city came out to meet Jesus; and when they saw him, they besought him that he would depart out of their coasts.

Chapter 9.Header: Jesus heals a man with palsy--Rejects the Jews with their baptism--Parable of wine and bottles
Chapter 9.1: And Jesus entered into a ship, and passed over, and came into his own city.
Chapter 9.2: And, behold, they brought to him a man sick of the palsy, lying on a bed; and Jesus, knowing their faith, said unto the sick of the palsy, Son, be of good cheer; thy sins be forgiven thee; go thy way and sin no more.
Chapter 9.3: And, behold, certain of the scribes said within themselves, This man blasphemeth.
Chapter 9.4: And Jesus, knowing their thoughts, said, Wherefore is it that ye think evil in your hearts?
Chapter 9.5: For is it not easier to say, Thy sins be forgiven thee, than to say, Arise and walk?
Chapter 9.6: But I said this that ye may know that the Son of Man hath power on earth to forgive sins.
Chapter 9.7: Then Jesus said unto the sick of the palsy, Arise, take up thy bed, and go unto thy house.
Chapter 9.8: And he immediately arose and departed to his house.
Chapter 9.9: But when the multitude saw it, they marveled and glorified God, who had given such power unto men.
Chapter 9.10: And as Jesus passed forth from thence, he saw a man named Matthew, sitting at the place where they received tribute, as was customary in those days; and he said unto him, Follow me. And he arose and followed him.
Chapter 9.11: And it came to pass, as Jesus sat at meat in the house, behold, many publicans and sinners came and sat down with him and with his disciples.
Chapter 9.12: And when the Pharisees saw them, they said unto his disciples, Why eateth your master with publicans and sinners?
Chapter 9.13: But when Jesus heard them, he said unto them, They that be whole need not a physician, but they that are sick.
Chapter 9.14: But go ye and learn what this meaneth: I will have mercy and not sacrifice; for I am not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.
Chapter 9.15: And while he was thus teaching, there came to him the disciples of John, saying, Why do we and the Pharisees fast oft, but thy disciples fast not?
Chapter 9.16: And Jesus said unto them, Can the children of the bride-chamber mourn, as long as the bridegroom is with them?
Chapter 9.17: But the days will come when the bridegroom shall be taken from them; and then shall they fast.
Chapter 9.18: Then said the Pharisees unto him, Why will ye not receive us with our baptism, seeing we keep the whole law?
Chapter 9.19: But Jesus said unto them, Ye keep not the law. If ye had kept the law, ye would have received me; for I am he who gave the law.
Chapter 9.20: I receive not you with your baptism because it profiteth you nothing.
Chapter 9.21: For when that which is new is come, the old is ready to be put away.
Chapter 9.22: For no man putteth a piece of new cloth on an old garment; for that which is put in to fill it up taketh from the garment, and the rent is made worse.
Chapter 9.23: Neither do men put new wine into old bottles, else the bottles break, and the wine runneth out, and the bottles perish; but they put new wine into new bottles, and both are preserved.
Chapter 9.24: While he spake these things unto them, behold, there came a certain ruler and worshiped him, saying, My daughter is even now dying; but come and lay thy hand upon her, and she shall live.
Chapter 9.25: And Jesus arose and followed him, and also his disciples; and much people thronged him.
Chapter 9.26: And, behold, a woman, which was diseased with an issue of blood twelve years, came behind him and touched the hem of his garment.
Chapter 9.27: For she said within herself, If I may but touch his garment, I shall be whole.
Chapter 9.28: But Jesus turned him about; and when he saw her, he said, Daughter, be of good comfort; thy faith hath made thee whole. And the woman was made whole from that hour.
Chapter 9.29: And when Jesus came into the ruler's house and saw the minstrels and the people making a noise,
Chapter 9.30: He said unto them, Give place; for the maid is not dead, but sleepeth. And they laughed him to scorn.
Chapter 9.31: But when the people were put forth, he went in and took her by the hand; and the maid arose.
Chapter 9.32: And the fame of Jesus went abroad into all that land.
Chapter 9.33: And when Jesus departed thence, two blind men followed him, crying and saying, Jesus, thou Son of David, have mercy on us.
Chapter 9.34: And when he was come into the house, the blind men came to him; and Jesus said unto them, Believe ye that I am able to do this? They said unto him, Yea, Lord.
Chapter 9.35: Then touched he their eyes, saying, According to your faith, be it unto you.
Chapter 9.36: And their eyes were opened; and straitly he charged them, saying, Keep my commandments, and see ye tell no man in this place, that no man know it.
Chapter 9.37: But they, when they were departed, spread abroad his fame in all that country.
Chapter 9.38: And as they went out, behold, they brought to him a dumb man possessed with a devil.
Chapter 9.39: And when the devil was cast out, the dumb man spake. And the multitudes marveled, saying, It was never so seen in Israel.
Chapter 9.40: But the Pharisees said, He casteth out the devils through the prince of the devils.
Chapter 9.41: And Jesus went about all the cities and villages, teaching in their synagogues, and preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing every sickness and disease among the people.
Chapter 9.42: But when he saw the multitudes, he was moved with compassion on them because they fainted and were scattered abroad, as sheep having no shepherd.
Chapter 9.43: Then said he unto his disciples, The harvest truly is plenteous, but the laborers are few.
Chapter 9.44: Pray ye, therefore, the Lord of the harvest, that he will send forth laborers into his harvest.

Chapter 10.Header: Christ calls the Twelve--Gives them power over unclean spirits--Instructs the Twelve and sends them forth
Chapter 10.:1: And when he had called unto him his twelve disciples, he gave them power over unclean spirits, to cast them out and to heal all manner of sickness and all manner of disease.
Chapter 10.:2: Now the names of the twelve apostles are these: the first, Simon, who is called Peter; and Andrew, his brother; James, the son of Zebedee, and John, his brother; Philip and Bartholomew; Thomas and , the publican; James, the son of Alpheus, and Lebbeus, whose surname was Thaddeus; Simon, the Canaanite; and Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed him.
Chapter 10.:3: These twelve Jesus sent forth and commanded them, saying,
Chapter 10.:4: Go not into the way of the Gentiles, and enter ye not into any city of the Samaritans.
Chapter 10.:5: But rather go to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.
Chapter 10.:6: And as ye go, preach, saying, The kingdom of heaven is at hand.
Chapter 10.:7: Heal the sick; cleanse the lepers; raise the dead; cast out devils; freely ye have received, freely give.
Chapter 10.:8: Provide neither gold, nor silver, nor brass in your purses,
Chapter 10.:9: Nor scrip for your journey, neither two coats, neither shoes, nor yet staves; for the workman is worthy of his meat.
Chapter 10.:10: And into whatsoever town or city ye shall enter, inquire who in it is worthy; and there abide till ye go thence.
Chapter 10.:11: And when ye come into a house, salute it; and if the house be worthy, let your peace come upon it; but if it be not worthy, let your peace return to you.
Chapter 10.:12: And whosoever shall not receive you nor hear your words, when ye depart out of that house or city, shake off the dust of your feet for a testimony against them.
Chapter 10.:13: And verily, I say unto you, it shall be more tolerable for the land of Sodom and Gomorrah in the day of judgment than for that city.
Chapter 10.:14: Behold, I send you forth as sheep in the midst of wolves; be ye, therefore, wise servants and as harmless as doves.
Chapter 10.:15: But, beware of men; for they will deliver you up to the councils, and they will scourge you in their synagogues.
Chapter 10.:16: And ye shall be brought before governors and kings for my sake, for a testimony against them and the Gentiles.
Chapter 10.:17: But when they deliver you up, take no thought how or what ye shall speak; for it shall be given you in that same hour what ye shall speak; for it is not ye that speak, but the Spirit of your Father which speaketh in you.
Chapter 10.:18: And the brother shall deliver up the brother to death, and the father the child; and the children shall rise up against their parents and cause them to be put to death.
Chapter 10.:19: And ye shall be hated of all the world for my name's sake; but he that endureth to the end shall be saved.
Chapter 10.:20: But when they persecute you in one city, flee ye into another; for verily, I say unto you, Ye shall not have gone over the cities of Israel till the Son of Man come.
Chapter 10.:21: Remember, the disciple is not above his master, nor the servant above his lord. It is enough that the disciple be as his master, and the servant as his lord.
Chapter 10.:22: If they have called the master of the house Beelzebub, how much more shall they call them of his household.
Chapter 10.:23: Fear them not, therefore; for there is nothing covered, that shall not be revealed; and hid, that shall not be known.
Chapter 10.:24: What I tell you in darkness, preach ye in light; and what ye hear in the ear, preach ye upon the housetops.
Chapter 10.:25: And fear not them who are able to kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul; but rather fear him who is able to destroy both soul and body in hell.
Chapter 10.:26: Are not two sparrows sold for a farthing? And one of them shall not fall to the ground without your Father knoweth it.
Chapter 10.:27: And the very hairs of your head are all numbered. Fear ye not, therefore; ye are of more value than many sparrows.
Chapter 10.:28: Whosoever, therefore, shall confess me before men, him will I confess also before my Father who is in heaven.
Chapter 10.:29: But whosoever shall deny me before men, him will I also deny before my Father who is in heaven.
Chapter 10.:30: Think not that I am come to send peace on earth; I came not to send peace, but a sword.
Chapter 10.:31: For I am come to set a man at variance against his father, and the daughter against her mother, and the daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law; and a man's foes shall be they of his own household.
Chapter 10.:32: He who loveth father and mother more than me is not worthy of me; and he who loveth son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.
Chapter 10.:33: And he who taketh not his cross and followeth after me is not worthy of me.
Chapter 10.:34: He who seeketh to save his life shall lose it; and he who loseth his life for my sake shall find it.
Chapter 10.:35: He who receiveth you, receiveth me; and he who receiveth me, receiveth him who sent me.
Chapter 10.:36: He that receiveth a prophet, in the name of a prophet, shall receive a prophet's reward.
Chapter 10.:37: He that receiveth a righteous man, in the name of a righteous man, shall receive a righteous man's reward.
Chapter 10.:38: And whosoever shall give to drink unto one of these little ones, a cup of cold water only, in the name of a disciple, verily, I say unto you, He shall in no wise lose his reward.

Chapter 11.Header: John sends his disciples to Christ--Testimony of Christ concerning John
Chapter 11.:1: And it came to pass, when Jesus had made an end of commanding his twelve disciples, he departed thence to teach and to preach in their cities.
Chapter 11.:2: Now when John had heard in the prison the works of Christ, he sent two of his disciples;
Chapter 11.:3: And they said unto him, Art thou he of whom it is written in the prophets that he should come, or do we look for another?
Chapter 11.:4: Jesus answered and said unto them, Go and tell John again of those things which ye do hear and see,
Chapter 11.:5: How the blind receive their sight, and the lame walk, and the lepers are cleansed, and the deaf hear, and the dead are raised up, and the poor have the gospel preached unto them.
Chapter 11.:6: And blessed is John and whosoever shall not be offended in me.
Chapter 11.:7: And as they departed, Jesus began to say unto the multitudes concerning John, What went ye out into the wilderness to see? Was it a reed shaken with the wind? And they answered him, No.
Chapter 11.:8: And he said, But what went ye out for to see? Was it a man clothed in soft raiment? Behold, they that wear soft raiment are in kings' houses.
Chapter 11.:9: But what went ye out for to see? a prophet? Yea, I say unto you, and more than a prophet.
Chapter 11.:10: For this is the one of whom it is written, Behold, I send my messenger before thy face, which shall prepare thy way before thee.
Chapter 11.:11: Verily, I say unto you, Among them that are born of women, there hath not risen a greater than John the Baptist; notwithstanding, he that is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he.
Chapter 11.:12: And from the days of John the Baptist until now, the kingdom of heaven suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force.
Chapter 11.:13: But the days will come when the violent shall have no power; for all the prophets and the law prophesied that it should be thus until John.
Chapter 11.:14: Yea, as many as have prophesied have foretold of these days.
Chapter 11.:15: And if ye will receive it, verily, he was the Elias, who was for to come and prepare all things.
Chapter 11.:16: He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.
Chapter 11.:17: But whereunto shall I liken this generation?
Chapter 11.:18: It is like unto children sitting in the markets, and calling unto their fellows, and saying, We have piped unto you, and ye have not danced; we have mourned for you, and ye have not lamented.
Chapter 11.:19: For John came neither eating nor drinking, and they say, He hath a devil.
Chapter 11.:20: The Son of Man came eating and drinking, and they say, Behold, a gluttonous man and a wine-bibber, a friend of publicans and sinners.
Chapter 11.:21: But I say unto you, Wisdom is justified of her children.
Chapter 11.:22: Then began he to upbraid the cities wherein most of his mighty works were done, because they repented not.
Chapter 11.:23: Woe unto thee, Chorazin! Woe unto thee, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works which were done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long since in sackcloth and ashes.
Chapter 11.:24: But I say unto you, It shall be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon at the day of judgment than for you.
Chapter 11.:25: And thou, Capernaum, which art exalted unto heaven, shalt be brought down to hell; for if the mighty works which have been done in thee had been done in Sodom, it would have remained until this day.
Chapter 11.:26: But I say unto you, It shall be more tolerable for the land of Sodom in the day of judgment than for thee.
Chapter 11.:27: And at that time, there came a voice out of heaven. And Jesus answered and said, I thank thee, O Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent and hast revealed them unto babes. Even so, Father, for so it seemed good in thy sight!
Chapter 11.:28: All things are delivered unto me of my Father; and no man knoweth the Son, but the Father; neither knoweth any man the Father, save the Son and they to whom the Son will reveal himself; they shall see the Father also.
Chapter 11.:29: Then spake Jesus, saying, Come unto me, all ye that labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.
Chapter 11.:30: Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart; and ye shall find rest unto your souls; for my yoke is easy, and my burden is light.

Chapter 12.Header: Jesus teaches the scribes and Pharisees--Restores a withered hand on the Sabbath day
Chapter 12.:1: At that time Jesus went on the Sabbath day through the corn; and his disciples were an hungered and began to pluck the ears of corn and to eat.
Chapter 12.:2: But when the Pharisees saw them, they said unto him, Behold, thy disciples do that which is not lawful to do upon the Sabbath day.
Chapter 12.:3: But he said unto them, Have ye not read what David did when he was an hungered, and they that were with him? How he entered into the house of God and did eat the showbread, which was not lawful for him to eat, neither for them that were with him, but only for the priests?
Chapter 12.:4: Or have ye not read in the law, how that on the Sabbath days the priests in the temple profane the Sabbath, and ye say they are blameless?
Chapter 12.:5: But I say unto you that in this place is one greater than the temple.
Chapter 12.:6: But if ye had known what this meaneth, I will have mercy and not sacrifice, ye would not have condemned the guiltless. For the Son of Man is Lord, even of the Sabbath.
Chapter 12.:7: And when he was departed thence, he went into their synagogues.
Chapter 12.:8: And, behold, there was a man which had a withered hand. And they asked him, saying, Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath days? that they might accuse him.
Chapter 12.:9: And he said unto them, What man shall there be among you that shall have one sheep, and if it fall into a pit on the Sabbath day, will he not lay hold on it and lift it out?
Chapter 12.:10: How much then is a man better than a sheep? Wherefore, it is lawful to do well on the Sabbath days.
Chapter 12.:11: Then said he to the man, Stretch forth thy hand; and he stretched it forth, and it was restored whole, like unto the other.
Chapter 12.:12: Then the Pharisees went out and held a council against him, how they might destroy him.
Chapter 12.:13: But Jesus knew when they took counsel, and he withdrew himself from thence; and great multitudes followed him; and he healed their sick and charged them that they should not make him known,
Chapter 12.:14: That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying, Behold my servant, whom I have chosen, my beloved, in whom my soul is well pleased.
Chapter 12.:15: I will put my Spirit upon him, and he shall show judgment to the Gentiles. He shall not strive nor cry; neither shall any man hear his voice in the streets.
Chapter 12.:16: A bruised reed shall he not break, and smoking flax shall he not quench till he send forth judgment unto victory.
Chapter 12.:17: And in his name shall the Gentiles trust.
Chapter 12.:18: Then was brought unto him one possessed with a devil, blind and dumb; and he healed him, insomuch that the blind and dumb both spake and saw.
Chapter 12.:19: And all the people were amazed and said, Is this the Son of David?
Chapter 12.:20: But when the Pharisees heard that he had cast out the devil, they said, This man doth not cast out devils, but by Beelzebub the prince of devils.
Chapter 12.:21: And Jesus knew their thoughts and said unto them, Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to desolation; and every city or house divided against itself shall not stand. And if Satan cast out Satan, he is divided against himself; how then shall his kingdom stand?
Chapter 12.:22: And if I by Beelzebub cast out devils, by whom do your children cast out devils? Therefore, they shall be your judges.
Chapter 12.:23: But if I cast out devils by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God is come unto you. For they also cast out devils by the Spirit of God, for unto them is given power over devils, that they may cast them out.
Chapter 12.:24: Or else, how can one enter into a strong man's house and spoil his goods, except he first bind the strong man, and then he will spoil his house?
Chapter 12.:25: He that is not with me is against me, and he that gathereth not with me scattereth abroad.
Chapter 12.:26: Wherefore, I say unto you, All manner of sin and blasphemy shall be forgiven unto men who receive me and repent; but the blasphemy against the Holy Ghost, it shall not be forgiven unto men.
Chapter 12.:27: And whosoever speaketh a word against the Son of Man, it shall be forgiven him; but whosoever speaketh against the Holy Ghost, it shall not be forgiven him, neither in this world, neither in the world to come.
Chapter 12.:28: Either make the tree good and his fruit good, or else make the tree corrupt and his fruit corrupt; for the tree is known by the fruit.
Chapter 12.:29: And Jesus said, O ye generation of vipers! How can ye, being evil, speak good things? For out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh.
Chapter 12.:30: A good man, out of the good treasure of the heart, bringeth forth good things; and an evil man, out of the evil treasure, bringeth forth evil things.
Chapter 12.:31: And again I say unto you that every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment.
Chapter 12.:32: For by thy words thou shalt be justified, and by thy words thou shalt be condemned.
Chapter 12.:33: Then certain of the scribes and of the Pharisees answered, saying, Master, we would see a sign from thee. But he answered and said unto them,
Chapter 12.:34: An evil and adulterous generation seeketh after a sign; and there shall no sign be given to it but the sign of the prophet Jonas; for as Jonas was three days and three nights in the whale's belly, so shall the Son of Man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.
Chapter 12.:35: The men of Nineveh shall rise up in judgment with this generation and shall condemn it, because they repented at the preaching of Jonas; and ye behold a greater than Jonas is here.
Chapter 12.:36: The queen of the south shall rise up in the day of judgment with this generation and shall condemn it; for she came from the uttermost parts of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and ye behold a greater than Solomon is here.
Chapter 12.:37: Then came some of the scribes and said unto him, Master, it is written that every sin shall be forgiven; but ye say, Whosoever speaketh against the Holy Ghost shall not be forgiven. And they asked him, saying, How can these things be?
Chapter 12.:38: And he said unto them, When the unclean spirit is gone out of a man, he walketh through dry places, seeking rest and finding none; but when a man speaketh against the Holy Ghost, then he saith, I will return into my house from whence I came out; and when he is come, he findeth him empty, swept, and garnished; for the good spirit leaveth him unto himself.
Chapter 12.:39: Then goeth the evil spirit and taketh with him seven other spirits more wicked than himself; and they enter in and dwell there; and the last end of that man is worse than the first. Even so shall it be also unto this wicked generation.
Chapter 12.:40: And while he yet talked with the people, behold, his mother and his brethren stood without, desiring to speak with him.
Chapter 12.:41: Then one said unto him, Behold, thy mother and thy brethren stand without, desiring to speak with thee.
Chapter 12.:42: But he answered and said unto the man that told him, Who is my mother? And who are my brethren?
Chapter 12.:43: And he stretched forth his hand toward his disciples and said, Behold my mother and my brethren!
Chapter 12.:44: And he gave them charge concerning her, saying, I go my way, for my Father hath sent me. And whosoever shall do the will of my Father which is in heaven, the same is my brother, and sister, and mother.

Chapter 13.Header: Jesus teaches the multitude in parables of the sower, the tares, and the mustard seed
Chapter 13.:1: And it came to pass the same day, Jesus went out of the house and sat by the seaside.
Chapter 13.:2: And great multitudes were gathered together unto him, so that he went into a ship and sat; and the whole multitude stood on the shore.
Chapter 13.:3: And he spake many things unto them in parables, saying, Behold, a sower went forth to sow.
Chapter 13.:4: And when he sowed, some seeds fell by the wayside, and the fowls came and devoured them up.
Chapter 13.:5: Some fell upon stony places, where they had not much earth; and forthwith they sprang up; and when the sun was up, they were scorched because they had no deepness of earth; and because they had no root, they withered away.
Chapter 13.:6: And some fell among thorns, and the thorns sprang up and choked them.
Chapter 13.:7: But others fell into good ground and brought forth fruit: some a hundredfold, some sixtyfold, and some thirtyfold. Who hath ears to hear, let him hear.
Chapter 13.:8: Then the disciples came and said unto him, Why speakest thou unto them in parables?
Chapter 13.:9: He answered and said unto them, Because it is given unto you to know the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, but to them it is not given.
Chapter 13.:10: For whosoever receiveth, to him shall be given, and he shall have more abundance;
Chapter 13.:11: But whosoever continueth not to receive, from him shall be taken away even that he hath.
Chapter 13.:12: Therefore, speak I to them in parables because they, seeing, see not; and hearing, they hear not; neither do they understand.
Chapter 13.:13: And in them is fulfilled the prophecy of Esaias concerning them, which saith, By hearing, ye shall hear and shall not understand; and seeing, ye shall see and shall not perceive.
Chapter 13.:14: For this people's heart is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes they have closed, lest at any time they should see with their eyes and hear with their ears, and should understand with their hearts, and should be converted, and I should heal them.
Chapter 13.:15: But blessed are your eyes, for they see, and your ears, for they hear. And blessed are you because these things are come unto you, that you might understand them.
Chapter 13.:16: And verily, I say unto you, Many righteous prophets have desired to see these days which you see, and have not seen them, and to hear that which you hear, and have not heard.
Chapter 13.:17: Hear ye, therefore, the parable of the sower.
Chapter 13.:18: When anyone heareth the word of the kingdom and understandeth not, then cometh the wicked one and catcheth away that which was sown in his heart; this is he who received seed by the wayside.
Chapter 13.:19: But he that received the seed into stony places, the same is he that heareth the word and readily with joy receiveth it, yet he hath not root in himself, and endureth but for a while; for when tribulation or persecution ariseth because of the word, by and by he is offended.
Chapter 13.:20: He also who received seed among the thorns is he that heareth the word; and the care of this world and the deceitfulness of riches choke the word, and he becometh unfruitful.
Chapter 13.:21: But he who received seed into the good ground is he who heareth the word and understandeth and endureth, which also beareth fruit and bringeth forth, some a hundredfold, some sixty, and some thirty.
Chapter 13.:22: Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is likened unto a man who sowed good seed in his field;
Chapter 13.:23: But while he slept, his enemy came, and sowed tares among the wheat, and went his way.
Chapter 13.:24: But when the blade sprang up and brought forth fruit, then appeared the tares also.
Chapter 13.:25: So the servants of the householder came and said unto him, Sir, didst not thou sow good seed in thy field? Whence then hath it tares?
Chapter 13.:26: He said unto them, An enemy hath done this.
Chapter 13.:27: And the servants said unto him, Wilt thou then that we go and gather them up?
Chapter 13.:28: But he said, Nay; lest while ye gather up the tares, ye root up also the wheat with them.
Chapter 13.:29: Let both grow together until the harvest; and in the time of harvest, I will say to the reapers, Gather ye together first the wheat into my barn; and the tares are bound in bundles to be burned.
Chapter 13.:30: And another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is like unto a grain of mustard seed, which a man took and sowed in his field;
Chapter 13.:31: Which indeed is the least of all seeds; but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs and becometh a tree, so that the birds of the air come and lodge in the branches thereof.
Chapter 13.:32: Another parable spake he unto them: The kingdom of heaven is like unto leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal until the whole was leavened.
Chapter 13.:33: All these things spake Jesus unto the multitudes in parables; and without a parable spake he not unto them,
Chapter 13.:34: That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophets, saying, I will open my mouth in parables; I will utter things which have been kept secret from the foundation of the world.
Chapter 13.:35: Then Jesus sent the multitude away and went into the house. And his disciples came unto him, saying, Declare unto us the parable of the tares of the field.
Chapter 13.:36: He answered and said unto them, He that soweth the good seed is the Son of Man.
Chapter 13.:37: The field is the world; the good seed are the children of the kingdom; but the tares are the children of the wicked.
Chapter 13.:38: The enemy that sowed them is the devil.
Chapter 13.:39: The harvest is the end of the world, or the destruction of the wicked.
Chapter 13.:40: The reapers are the angels, or the messengers sent of heaven.
Chapter 13.:41: As, therefore, the tares are gathered and burned in the fire, so shall it be in the end of this world, or the destruction of the wicked.
Chapter 13.:42: For in that day, before the Son of Man shall come, he shall send forth his angels and messengers of heaven.
Chapter 13.:43: And they shall gather out of his kingdom all things which offend, and them which do iniquity, and shall cast them out among the wicked; and there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth.
Chapter 13.:44: For the world shall be burned with fire.
Chapter 13.:45: Then shall the righteous shine forth as the sun in the kingdom of their Father. Who hath ears to hear, let him hear.
Chapter 13.:46: Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto a treasure hid in a field. And when a man hath found a treasure which is hid, he secureth it and, straightway, for joy thereof, goeth, and selleth all that he hath, and buyeth that field.
Chapter 13.:47: And again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto a merchant-man, seeking goodly pearls, who, when he had found one pearl of great price, went and sold all that he had and bought it.
Chapter 13.:48: Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto a net that was cast into the sea and gathered of every kind, which, when it was full, they drew to shore, and sat down, and gathered the good into vessels, but cast the bad away.
Chapter 13.:49: So shall it be at the end of the world.
Chapter 13.:50: And the world is the children of the wicked.
Chapter 13.:51: The angels shall come forth, and sever the wicked from among the just, and shall cast them out into the world to be burned. There shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth.
Chapter 13.:52: Then Jesus said unto them, Have ye understood all these things? They say unto him, Yea, Lord.
Chapter 13.:53: Then said he unto them, Every scribe well instructed in the things of the kingdom of heaven is like unto a householder: a man, therefore, which bringeth forth out of his treasure that which is new and old.
Chapter 13.:54: And it came to pass, when Jesus had finished these parables, he departed thence.
Chapter 13.:55: And when he was come into his own country, he taught them in their synagogues, insomuch that they were astonished and said, Whence hath this Jesus this wisdom and these mighty works?
Chapter 13.:56: Is not this the carpenter's son? Is not his mother called Mary? And his brethren, James, and Joses, and Simon, and Judas? And his sisters, are they not all with us?
Chapter 13.:57: Whence then hath this man all these things? And they were offended at him.
Chapter 13.:58: But Jesus said unto them, A prophet is not without honor, save in his own country and in his own house.
Chapter 13.:59: And he did not many mighty works there because of their unbelief.

Chapter 14.Header: John the Baptist beheaded--A multitude miraculously fed--Jesus walks on water
Chapter 14.:1: At that time, Herod the tetrarch heard of the fame of Jesus and said unto his servants, This is John the Baptist; he is risen from the dead, and, therefore, mighty works do show forth themselves in him.
Chapter 14.:2: For Herod had laid hold on John, and bound him, and put him in prison for Herodias' sake, his brother Philip's wife.
Chapter 14.:3: For John said unto him, It is not lawful for thee to have her.
Chapter 14.:4: And when he would have put him to death, he feared the multitude because they counted him as a prophet.
Chapter 14.:5: But when Herod's birthday was kept, the daughter of Herodias danced before them and pleased Herod.
Chapter 14.:6: Whereupon he promised with an oath to give her whatever she would ask.
Chapter 14.:7: And she, being before instructed of her mother, said, Give me here, John Baptist's head in a charger.
Chapter 14.:8: And the king was sorry; nevertheless for the oath's sake, and them which sat with him at meat, he commanded it to be given.
Chapter 14.:9: And he sent and beheaded John in the prison.
Chapter 14.:10: And his head was brought in a charger and given to the damsel; and she brought it to her mother.
Chapter 14.:11: And his disciples came and took up the body, and buried it, and went and told Jesus.
Chapter 14.:12: When Jesus heard that John was beheaded, he departed thence by ship into a desert place apart; and when the people had heard of him, they followed him on foot out of the cities.
Chapter 14.:13: And Jesus went forth, and saw a great multitude, and was moved with compassion towards them, and he healed their sick.
Chapter 14.:14: And when it was evening, his disciples came to him, saying, This is a desert place, and the time is now past; send the multitude away, that they may go into the villages and buy themselves victuals.
Chapter 14.:15: But Jesus said unto them, They need not depart; give ye them to eat.
Chapter 14.:16: And they said unto him, We have here but five loaves and two fishes. He said, Bring them hither to me.
Chapter 14.:17: And he commanded the multitude to sit down on the grass; and he took the five loaves and the two fishes, and looking up to heaven, he blessed and broke, and gave the loaves to the disciples, and the disciples, to the multitude.
Chapter 14.:18: And they did all eat and were filled. And they took up of the fragments that remained, twelve baskets full. And they that had eaten were about five thousand men, besides women and children.
Chapter 14.:19: And straightway Jesus constrained his disciples to get into a ship and to go before him unto the other side, while he sent the multitudes away. And when he had sent the multitudes away, he went up into a mountain, apart, to pray.
Chapter 14.:20: And when the evening was come, he was there alone. But the ship was now in the midst of the sea, tossed with the waves; for the wind was contrary.
Chapter 14.:21: And in the fourth watch of the night, Jesus went unto them, walking on the sea.
Chapter 14.:22: And when the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were troubled, saying, It is a spirit; and they cried out for fear.
Chapter 14.:23: But straightway Jesus spake unto them, saying, Be of good cheer; it is I. Be not afraid.
Chapter 14.:24: And Peter answered him and said, Lord, if it be thou, bid me come unto thee on the water. And he said, Come.
Chapter 14.:25: And when Peter was come down out of the ship, he walked on the water to go to Jesus. But when he saw the wind boisterous, he was afraid; and, beginning to sink, he cried, saying, Lord, save me.
Chapter 14.:26: And immediately Jesus stretched forth his hand, and caught him, and said unto him, O thou of little faith, wherefore didst thou doubt?
Chapter 14.:27: And when they were come into the ship, the wind ceased.
Chapter 14.:28: Then they that were in the ship came and worshiped him, saying, Of a truth, thou art the Son of God.
Chapter 14.:29: And when they were gone over, they came into the land of Gennesaret.
Chapter 14.:30: And when the men of that place had knowledge of him, they sent out into all that country round about, and brought unto him all that were diseased, and besought him that they might only touch the hem of his garment; and as many as touched were made perfectly whole.

Chapter 15.Header: Christ goes into the coasts of Tyre and Sidon--Great multitudes come to him--He heals the lame, the blind, and dumb
Chapter 15.:1: Then came to Jesus, scribes and Pharisees, which were of Jerusalem, saying,
Chapter 15.:2: Why do thy disciples transgress the tradition of the elders? For they wash not their hands when they eat bread.
Chapter 15.:3: But he answered and said unto them, Why do ye also transgress the commandment of God by your tradition?
Chapter 15.:4: For God commanded, saying, Honor thy father and mother; and, He that curseth father or mother, let him die the death which Moses shall appoint.
Chapter 15.:5: But ye say, Whosoever shall say to father or mother, By whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me, it is a gift from me, and honor not his father or mother, it is well.
Chapter 15.:6: Thus have ye made the commandment of God of none effect by your tradition.
Chapter 15.:7: O ye hypocrites! Well did Esaias prophesy of you, saying, This people draw nigh unto me with their mouth and honoreth me with their lips, but their heart is far from me.
Chapter 15.:8: But in vain do they worship me, teaching the doctrines and the commandments of men.
Chapter 15.:9: And he called the multitude and said unto them, Hear and understand.
Chapter 15.:10: Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man; but that which cometh out of the mouth, this defileth the man.
Chapter 15.:11: Then came his disciples and said unto him, Knowest thou that the Pharisees were offended after they heard this saying?
Chapter 15.:12: But he answered and said, Every plant which my heavenly Father hath not planted shall be rooted up.
Chapter 15.:13: Let them alone; they be blind leaders of the blind; and if the blind lead the blind, both shall fall into the ditch.
Chapter 15.:14: Then answered Peter and said unto him, Declare unto us this parable.
Chapter 15.:15: And Jesus said, Are ye also yet without understanding?
Chapter 15.:16: Do ye not yet understand that whatsoever entereth in at the mouth goeth into the belly and is cast into the draught?
Chapter 15.:17: But those things which proceed out of the mouth come forth from the heart; and they defile the man.
Chapter 15.:18: For out of the heart proceed evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witness, blasphemies;
Chapter 15.:19: These are things which defile a man. But to eat with unwashen hands defileth not a man.
Chapter 15.:20: Then Jesus went thence and departed into the coasts of Tyre and Sidon.
Chapter 15.:21: And, behold, a woman of Canaan came out of the same coasts and cried unto him, saying, Have mercy on me, O Lord, thou Son of David; my daughter is grievously vexed with a devil.
Chapter 15.:22: But he answered her not a word. And his disciples came and besought him, saying, Send her away; for she crieth after us.
Chapter 15.:23: He answered, I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel.
Chapter 15.:24: Then came she and worshiped him, saying, Lord, help me.
Chapter 15.:25: But he answered and said, It is not meet to take the children's bread and cast it to dogs.
Chapter 15.:26: And she said, Truth, Lord; yet the dogs eat the crumbs that fall from the master's table.
Chapter 15.:27: Then Jesus answered and said unto her, O woman, great is thy faith; be it unto thee even as thou wilt. And her daughter was made whole from that very hour.
Chapter 15.:28: And Jesus departed from thence, and came nigh unto the sea of Galilee, and went up into a mountain, and sat down there.
Chapter 15.:29: And great multitudes came unto him, having with them some lame, blind, dumb, maimed, and many others, and cast them down at Jesus' feet; and he healed them, insomuch that the multitude wondered when they saw the dumb to speak, the maimed to be whole, the lame to walk, and the blind to see. And they glorified the God of Israel.
Chapter 15.:30: Then Jesus called his disciples and said, I have compassion on the multitude because they continue with me now three days and have nothing to eat; and I will not send them away fasting, lest they faint in the way.
Chapter 15.:31: And his disciples said unto him, Whence should we have so much bread in the wilderness, as to fill so great a multitude?
Chapter 15.:32: And Jesus said unto them, How many loaves have ye? And they said, Seven, and a few little fishes.
Chapter 15.:33: And he commanded the multitude to sit down on the ground.
Chapter 15.:34: And he took the seven loaves and the fishes, and gave thanks, and brake the bread, and gave to his disciples, and the disciples, to the multitude.
Chapter 15.:35: And they did all eat and were filled. And they took up of the broken meat, seven baskets full.
Chapter 15.:36: And they that did eat were four thousand men, besides women and children.
Chapter 15.:37: And he sent away the multitude, and took ship, and came into the coasts of Magdala.

Chapter 16.Header: Jesus warns of the doctrine of Pharisees and Sadducees--Asks his disciples who men say he is--Delivers keys of the kingdom to Peter
Chapter 16.:1: The Pharisees also, with the Sadducees, came, and, tempting Jesus, desired him that he would show them a sign from heaven.
Chapter 16.:2: And he answered and said unto them, When it is evening, ye say, The weather is fair, for the sky is red; and in the morning ye say, The weather is foul today, for the sky is red and lowering.
Chapter 16.:3: O hypocrites! Ye can discern the face of the sky; but ye cannot tell the signs of the times.
Chapter 16.:4: A wicked and adulterous generation seeketh after a sign; and there shall no sign be given unto it but the sign of the prophet Jonas.
Chapter 16.:5: And he left them and departed.
Chapter 16.:6: And when his disciples were come to the other side, they had forgotten to take bread.
