Chapter 16.:7: Then Jesus said unto them, Take heed and beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees.
Chapter 16.:8: And they reasoned among themselves, saying, He said this because we have taken no bread.
Chapter 16.:9: And when they reasoned among themselves, Jesus perceived it; and he said unto them, O ye of little faith! Why reason ye among yourselves because ye have brought no bread?
Chapter 16.:10: Do ye not yet understand, neither remember the five loaves of the five thousand, and how many baskets ye took up?
Chapter 16.:11: Neither the seven loaves of the four thousand, and how many baskets ye took up?
Chapter 16.:12: How is it that you do not understand that I spoke not unto you concerning bread, that you should beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees?
Chapter 16.:13: Then understood they, how that he bade them not beware of the leaven of bread, but of the doctrine of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees.
Chapter 16.:14: And when Jesus came into the coasts of Caesarea Philippi, he asked his disciples, saying, Whom do men say that I, the Son of Man, am?
Chapter 16.:15: And they said, Some say John the Baptist; some Elias; and others Jeremias, or one of the prophets.
Chapter 16.:16: He said unto them, But whom say ye that I am?
Chapter 16.:17: And Simon Peter answered and said, Thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God.
Chapter 16.:18: And Jesus answered and said unto him, Blessed art thou, Simon Bar-Jona, for flesh and blood hath not revealed this unto thee, but my Father who is in heaven.
Chapter 16.:19: And I say also unto thee, That thou art Peter; and upon this rock I will build my church, and the gates of hell shall not prevail against it.
Chapter 16.:20: And I will give unto thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven; and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be bound in heaven; and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.
Chapter 16.:21: Then charged he his disciples that they should tell no man that he was Jesus, the Christ.
Chapter 16.:22: From that time forth began Jesus to show unto his disciples how that he must go to Jerusalem, and suffer many things of the elders, and chief priests, and scribes, and be killed, and be raised again the third day.
Chapter 16.:23: Then Peter took him and began to rebuke him, saying, Be it far from thee, Lord; this shall not be done unto thee.
Chapter 16.:24: But he turned and said unto Peter, Get thee behind me, Satan; thou art an offense unto me; for thou savorest not the things that be of God, but those that be of men.
Chapter 16.:25: Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
Chapter 16.:26: And now for a man to take up his cross is to deny himself all ungodliness, and every worldly lust, and keep my commandments.
Chapter 16.:27: Break not my commandments for to save your lives; for whosoever will save his life in this world shall lose it in the world to come.
Chapter 16.:28: And whosoever will lose his life in this world for my sake shall find it in the world to come.
Chapter 16.:29: Therefore, forsake the world and save your souls; for what is a man profited if he shall gain the whole world and lose his own soul? Or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?
Chapter 16.:30: For the Son of Man shall come in the glory of his Father, with his angels; and then he shall reward every man according to his works.
Chapter 16.:31: Verily, I say unto you, There be some standing here which shall not taste of death till they see the Son of Man coming in his kingdom.

Chapter 17.:1: And after six days, Jesus taketh Peter, James, and John, his brother, and bringeth them up into a high mountain, apart, and was transfigured before them; and his face did shine as the sun, and his raiment was white as the light.
Chapter 17.:2: And, behold, there appeared unto them Moses and Elias, talking with him.
Chapter 17.:3: Then answered Peter and said unto Jesus, Lord, it is good for us to be here; if thou wilt, let us make here three tabernacles: one for thee, one for Moses, and one for Elias.
Chapter 17.:4: While he yet spake, behold, a bright cloud overshadowed them; and, behold, a voice out of the cloud, which said, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased; hear ye him.
Chapter 17.:5: And when the disciples heard the voice, they fell on their faces and were sore afraid.
Chapter 17.:6: And Jesus came, and touched them, and said, Arise, and be not afraid.
Chapter 17.:7: And when they had lifted up their eyes, they saw no man, save Jesus only.
Chapter 17.:8: And as they came down from the mountain, Jesus charged them, saying, Tell the vision to no man until the Son of Man be risen again from the dead.
Chapter 17.:9: And his disciples asked him, saying, Why then say the scribes that Elias must first come?
Chapter 17.:10: And Jesus answered and said unto them, Elias truly shall first come and restore all things, as the prophets have written.
Chapter 17.:11: And again I say unto you that Elias has come already, concerning whom it is written, Behold, I will send my messenger, and he shall prepare the way before me; and they knew him not and have done unto him whatsoever they listed.
Chapter 17.:12: Likewise shall also the Son of Man suffer of them.
Chapter 17.:13: But I say unto you, Who is Elias? Behold, this is Elias, whom I send to prepare the way before me.
Chapter 17.:14: Then the disciples understood that he spake unto them of John the Baptist, and also of another, who should come and restore all things, as it is written by the prophets.
Chapter 17.:15: And when they were come to the multitude, there came to him a man kneeling down to him and saying, Lord, have mercy on my son; for he is lunatic and sore vexed; for ofttimes he falleth into the fire, and oft into the water.
Chapter 17.:16: And I brought him to thy disciples, and they could not cure him.
Chapter 17.:17: Then Jesus answered and said, O faithless and perverse generation! How long shall I be with you? How long shall I suffer you? Bring him hither to me.
Chapter 17.:18: And Jesus rebuked the devil, and he departed out of him; and the child was cured from that very hour.
Chapter 17.:19: Then came the disciples to Jesus, apart, and said, Why could not we cast him out?
Chapter 17.:20: And Jesus said unto them, Because of your unbelief; for, verily, I say unto you, If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye shall say unto this mountain, Remove to yonder place, and it shall remove; and nothing shall be impossible unto you.
Chapter 17.:21: Howbeit, this kind goeth not out but by prayer and fasting.
Chapter 17.:22: And while they abode in Galilee, Jesus said unto them, The Son of Man shall be betrayed into the hands of men; and they shall kill him; and the third day he shall be raised again. And they were exceeding sorry.
Chapter 17.:23: And when they were come to Capernaum, they that received tribute came to Peter and said, Doth not your master pay tribute? He said, Yea.
Chapter 17.:24: And when he was come into the house, Jesus rebuked him, saying,
Chapter 17.:25: What thinkest thou, Simon? Of whom do the kings of the earth take custom, or tribute? of their own children, or of strangers?
Chapter 17.:26: Peter said unto him, Of strangers. Jesus said unto him, Then are the children free. Notwithstanding, lest we should offend them, go thou to the sea, and cast a hook, and take up the fish that first cometh up; and when thou hast opened his mouth, thou shalt find a piece of money; that take and give unto them for me and thee.

Chapter 18.Header: The parable of the lord and his servants--Likened unto the kingdom of heaven
Chapter 18.:1: At the same time came the disciples unto Jesus, saying, Who is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven?
Chapter 18.:2: And Jesus called a little child unto him, and set him in the midst of them, and said, Verily, I say unto you, Except ye be converted and become as little children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven.
Chapter 18.:3: Whosoever, therefore, shall humble himself as this little child, the same is greatest in the kingdom of heaven.
Chapter 18.:4: And whosoever shall receive one such little child in my name receiveth me.
Chapter 18.:5: But whoso shall offend one of these little ones which believe in me, it were better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck and he were drowned in the depth of the sea.
Chapter 18.:6: Woe unto the world because of offenses! For it must needs be that offenses come; but woe to that man by whom the offense cometh!
Chapter 18.:7: Wherefore, if thy hand or thy foot offend thee, cut it off and cast it from thee; for it is better for thee to enter into life halt or maimed, rather than, having two hands or two feet, to be cast into everlasting fire.
Chapter 18.:8: And if thine eye offend thee, pluck it out and cast it from thee; it is better for thee to enter into life with one eye, rather than, having two eyes, to be cast into hellfire.
Chapter 18.:9: And a man's hand is his friend, and his foot, also; and a man's eye are they of his own household.
Chapter 18.:10: Take heed that ye despise not one of these little ones; for I say unto you that in heaven their angels do always behold the face of my Father who is in heaven.
Chapter 18.:11: For the Son of Man is come to save that which was lost and to call sinners to repentance; but these little ones have no need of repentance, and I will save them.
Chapter 18.:12: How think ye? If a man have a hundred sheep and one of them be gone astray, doth he not leave the ninety and nine, and goeth into the mountains, and seeketh that which is gone astray?
Chapter 18.:13: And if it so be that he find it, verily, I say unto you, He rejoiceth more over that which was lost than over the ninety and nine which went not astray.
Chapter 18.:14: Even so, it is not the will of your Father which is in heaven that one of these little ones should perish.
Chapter 18.:15: Moreover, if thy brother shall trespass against thee, go and tell him his fault between thee and him alone; if he shall hear thee, thou hast gained thy brother.
Chapter 18.:16: But if he will not hear thee, then take with thee one or two more, that in the mouth of two or three witnesses every word may be established.
Chapter 18.:17: And if he shall neglect to hear them, tell it unto the church; but if he neglect to hear the church, let him be unto you as a heathen man and a publican.
Chapter 18.:18: Verily, I say unto you, Whatsoever ye shall bind on earth shall be bound in heaven; and whatsoever ye shall loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.
Chapter 18.:19: Again, I say unto you that if two of you shall agree on earth as touching any thing that they shall ask, that they may not ask amiss, it shall be done for them of my Father who is in heaven.
Chapter 18.:20: For where two or three are gathered together in my name, there am I in the midst of them.
Chapter 18.:21: Then came Peter to him and said, Lord, how oft shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? till seven times?
Chapter 18.:22: Jesus said unto him, I say not unto thee until seven times, but until seventy times seven.
Chapter 18.:23: Therefore is the kingdom of heaven likened unto a certain king, who would take account of his servants.
Chapter 18.:24: And when he had begun to reckon, one was brought unto him who owed him ten thousand talents.
Chapter 18.:25: But forasmuch as he had not to pay, his lord commanded him to be sold, and his wife, and children, and all that he had, and payment to be made.
Chapter 18.:26: And the servant besought him, saying, Lord, have patience with me, and I will pay thee all.
Chapter 18.:27: Then the lord of that servant was moved with compassion, and loosed him, and forgave him the debt. The servant, therefore, fell down and worshiped him.
Chapter 18.:28: But the same servant went out and found one of his fellow servants which owed him a hundred pence; and he laid hands on him and took him by the throat, saying, Pay me that thou owest.
Chapter 18.:29: And his fellow servant fell down at his feet and besought him, saying, Have patience with me, and I will pay thee all.
Chapter 18.:30: And he would not; but went and cast him into prison till he should pay the debt.
Chapter 18.:31: So when his fellow servants saw what was done, they were very sorry, and came, and told unto their lord all that was done.
Chapter 18.:32: Then his lord, after that he had called him, said unto him, O thou wicked servant! I forgave thee all that debt because thou desiredst me; shouldest not thou also have had compassion on thy fellow servant, even as I had pity on thee?
Chapter 18.:33: And his lord was wroth and delivered him to the tormentors till he should pay all that was due unto him.
Chapter 18.:34: So likewise shall my heavenly Father do also unto you, if ye from your hearts forgive not everyone his brother their trespasses.

Chapter 19.Header: The Pharisees, tempting Christ, ask if it be lawful to put away one's wife
Chapter 19.:1: And it came to pass, when Jesus had finished these sayings, he departed from Galilee and came into the coasts of Judea beyond Jordan.
Chapter 19.:2: And great multitudes followed him; and many believed on him, and he healed them there.
Chapter 19.:3: The Pharisees came also unto him, tempting him, and saying unto him, Is it lawful for a man to put away his wife for every cause?
Chapter 19.:4: And he answered and said unto them, Have ye not read that he who made man at the beginning made him, male and female,
Chapter 19.:5: And said, For this cause shall a man leave father and mother and shall cleave unto his wife; and they twain shall be one flesh?
Chapter 19.:6: Wherefore they are no more twain, but one flesh. What, therefore, God hath joined together let not man put asunder.
Chapter 19.:7: They said unto him, Why did Moses then command to give a writing of divorcement and to put her away?
Chapter 19.:8: He said unto them, Moses, because of the hardness of your hearts, suffered you to put away your wives; but from the beginning it was not so.
Chapter 19.:9: And I say unto you, Whosoever shall put away his wife, except for fornication, and shall marry another committeth adultery; and whoso marrieth her that is put away doth commit adultery.
Chapter 19.:10: His disciples said unto him, If the case of the man be so with a wife, it is not good to marry.
Chapter 19.:11: But he said unto them, All cannot receive this saying; it is not for them save to whom it is given.
Chapter 19.:12: For there are some eunuchs which were so born from their mother's womb; and there are some eunuchs which were made eunuchs of men; and there be eunuchs which have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake. He that is able to receive, let him receive my sayings.
Chapter 19.:13: Then were there brought unto him little children, that he should put his hands on them and pray. And the disciples rebuked them, saying, There is no need, for Jesus hath said, Such shall be saved.
Chapter 19.:14: But Jesus said, Suffer little children to come unto me, and forbid them not; for of such is the kingdom of heaven.
Chapter 19.:15: And he laid hands on them and departed thence.
Chapter 19.:16: And, behold, one came and said, Good master, what good thing shall I do, that I may have eternal life?
Chapter 19.:17: And he said unto him, Why callest thou me good? There is none good but one, that is God; but if thou wilt enter into life, keep the commandments.
Chapter 19.:18: He saith unto him, Which? Jesus said, Thou shalt not kill. Thou shalt not commit adultery. Thou shalt not steal. Thou shalt not bear false witness.
Chapter 19.:19: Honor thy father and mother. And, Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself.
Chapter 19.:20: The young man saith unto him, All these things have I kept from my youth up. What lack I yet?
Chapter 19.:21: Jesus said unto him, If thou wilt be perfect, go, sell that thou hast, and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven; and come and follow me.
Chapter 19.:22: But when the young man heard that saying, he went away sorrowful; for he had great possessions.
Chapter 19.:23: Then said Jesus unto his disciples, Verily, I say unto you that a rich man shall hardly enter into the kingdom of heaven.
Chapter 19.:24: And again I say unto you, It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God.
Chapter 19.:25: When his disciples heard this, they were exceedingly amazed, saying, Who then can be saved?
Chapter 19.:26: But Jesus beheld their thoughts and said unto them, With men this is impossible; but if they will forsake all things for my sake, with God whatsoever things I speak are possible.
Chapter 19.:27: Then answered Peter and said unto him, Behold, we have forsaken all and followed thee. What shall we have therefore?
Chapter 19.:28: And Jesus said unto them, Verily, I say unto you that ye who have followed me shall, in the resurrection, when the Son of Man shall come sitting on the throne of his glory, ye shall also sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
Chapter 19.:29: And everyone that has forsaken houses, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, for my name's sake, shall receive a hundredfold and shall inherit everlasting life.
Chapter 19.:30: But many of the first shall be last, and the last first.

Chapter 20.Header: The kingdom of heaven likened unto a man hiring laborers in his vineyard
Chapter 20.:1: For the kingdom of heaven is like unto a man, a householder, who went out early in the morning to hire laborers into his vineyard.
Chapter 20.:2: And when he had agreed with the laborers for a penny a day, he sent them into his vineyard.
Chapter 20.:3: And he went out about the third hour, and found others standing idle in the market place,
Chapter 20.:4: And said unto them, Go ye also into the vineyard, and whatsoever is right, I will give you; and they went their way.
Chapter 20.:5: And again he went out about the sixth and ninth hour and did likewise.
Chapter 20.:6: And about the eleventh hour he went out, and found others standing idle, and said unto them, Why stand ye here all the day idle?
Chapter 20.:7: They said unto him, Because no man hath hired us.
Chapter 20.:8: He said unto them, Go ye also into the vineyard; and whatsoever is right, ye shall receive.
Chapter 20.:9: So when even was come, the lord of the vineyard said unto his steward, Call the laborers and give them their hire, beginning from the last unto the first.
Chapter 20.:10: And when they came that began about the eleventh hour, they received every man a penny.
Chapter 20.:11: But when the first came, they supposed that they should have received more; and they likewise received every man a penny. And when they had received a penny, they murmured against the good man of the house, saying, These last have wrought one hour only, and thou hast made them equal unto us, who have borne the burden and the heat of the day.
Chapter 20.:12: But he answered one of them, and said, Friend, I do thee no wrong; didst not thou agree with me for a penny?
Chapter 20.:13: Take thine and go thy way; I will give unto this last even as unto thee. Is it not lawful for me to do what I will with mine own?
Chapter 20.:14: Is thine eye evil because I am good?
Chapter 20.:15: So the last shall be first, and the first last; for many are called, but few chosen.
Chapter 20.:16: And Jesus, going up to Jerusalem, took the twelve disciples apart in the way and said unto them,
Chapter 20.:17: Behold, we go up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man shall be betrayed unto the chief priests and unto the scribes; and they shall condemn him to death, and shall deliver him to the Gentiles to mock, and to scourge, and to crucify. And the third day he shall rise again.
Chapter 20.:18: Then came to him the mother of Zebedee's children with her sons, worshiping Jesus and desiring a certain thing of him.
Chapter 20.:19: And he said unto her, What wilt thou that I should do?
Chapter 20.:20: And she said unto him, Grant that these my two sons may sit, the one on thy right hand and the other on thy left, in thy kingdom.
Chapter 20.:21: But Jesus answered and said, Ye know not what ye ask. Are ye able to drink of the cup that I shall drink of, and to be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with?
Chapter 20.:22: They said unto him, We are able.
Chapter 20.:23: And he said unto them, Ye shall drink indeed of my cup, and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with; but to sit on my right hand and on my left is for whom it is prepared of my Father, but not mine to give.
Chapter 20.:24: And when the ten heard this, they were moved with indignation against the two brethren.
Chapter 20.:25: But Jesus called them and said, Ye know that the princes of the Gentiles exercise dominion over them, and they that are great exercise authority upon them; but it shall not be so among you.
Chapter 20.:26: But whosoever will be great among you, let him be your minister.
Chapter 20.:27: And whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your servant,
Chapter 20.:28: Even as the Son of Man came, not to be ministered unto, but to minister and to give his life a ransom for many.
Chapter 20.:29: And as they departed from Jericho, a great multitude followed him.
Chapter 20.:30: And, behold, two blind men sitting by the wayside, when they heard that Jesus passed by, cried out, saying, Have mercy on us, O Lord, Son of David.
Chapter 20.:31: And the multitude rebuked them, saying they should hold their peace; but they cried the more, saying, Have mercy on us, O Lord, Son of David.
Chapter 20.:32: And Jesus stood still, and called them, and said, What will ye that I shall do unto you?
Chapter 20.:33: They said unto him, Lord, that our eyes may be opened.
Chapter 20.:34: So Jesus had compassion and touched their eyes; and immediately their eyes received sight, and they followed him.

Chapter 21.Header: Christ rides into Jerusalem on a colt
Chapter 21.:1: And when Jesus drew nigh unto Jerusalem, and they were come to Bethphage, unto the mount of Olives, then sent Jesus two disciples,
Chapter 21.:2: Saying unto them, Go into the village over against you, and straightway ye shall find a colt tied; loose it and bring it unto me; and if any shall say aught unto you, ye shall say, The Lord hath need of it; and straightway he will send it.
Chapter 21.:3: All this was done, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, saying,
Chapter 21.:4: Tell ye the daughter of Zion, Behold, thy king cometh unto thee, and he is meek, and he is sitting upon an ass, and a colt, the foal of an ass.
Chapter 21.:5: And the disciples went and did as Jesus commanded them, and brought the colt, and put on it their clothes; and Jesus took the colt and sat thereon; and they followed him.
Chapter 21.:6: And a very great multitude spread their garments in the way; others cut down branches from the trees and strewed in the way.
Chapter 21.:7: And the multitudes that went before, and also that followed after, cried, saying, Hosanna to the Son of David; blessed is he who cometh in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest!
Chapter 21.:8: And when he was come into Jerusalem, all the city was moved, saying, Who is this?
Chapter 21.:9: And the multitude said, This is Jesus of Nazareth, the prophet of Galilee.
Chapter 21.:10: And Jesus went into the temple of God, and cast out all them that sold and bought in the temple, and overthrew the tables of the moneychangers and the seats of them that sold doves, and said unto them,
Chapter 21.:11: It is written, My house shall be called the house of prayer; but ye have made it a den of thieves.
Chapter 21.:12: And the blind and the lame came to him in the temple; and he healed them.
Chapter 21.:13: And when the chief priests and scribes saw the wonderful things that he did, and the children of the kingdom crying in the temple and saying, Hosanna to the Son of David, they were sore displeased and said unto him, Hearest thou what these say?
Chapter 21.:14: And Jesus said unto them, Yea. Have ye never read the scriptures which saith, Out of the mouths of babes and sucklings, O Lord, thou hast perfected praise?
Chapter 21.:15: And he left them, and went out of the city unto Bethany, and he lodged there.
Chapter 21.:16: Now in the morning, as he returned into the city, he hungered.
Chapter 21.:17: And when he saw a fig tree in the way, he came to it; and there was not any fruit on it, but leaves only. And he said unto it, Let no fruit grow on thee henceforward, forever. And presently the fig tree withered away.
Chapter 21.:18: And when the disciples saw this, they marveled and said, How soon is the fig tree withered away!
Chapter 21.:19: Jesus answered and said unto them, Verily, I say unto you, If ye have faith and doubt not, ye shall not only do this to the fig tree, but also, if ye shall say unto this mountain, Be thou removed, and be thou cast into the sea, it shall be done.
Chapter 21.:20: And all things, whatsoever ye shall ask in prayer, in faith believing, ye shall receive.
Chapter 21.:21: And when he was come into the temple, the chief priests and the elders of the people came unto him as he was teaching and said, By what authority doest thou these things? And who gave thee this authority?
Chapter 21.:22: And Jesus answered and said unto them, I also will ask you one thing, which if ye tell me, I, likewise, will tell you by what authority I do these things.
Chapter 21.:23: The baptism of John, whence was it? from heaven or of men?
Chapter 21.:24: And they reasoned with themselves, saying, If we shall say, From heaven, he will say unto us, Why did ye not then believe him? But if we shall say, Of men, we fear the people. For all people held John as a prophet. And they answered Jesus and said, We cannot tell.
Chapter 21.:25: And he said, Neither tell I you by what authority I do these things.
Chapter 21.:26: But what think ye? A man had two sons; and he came to the first, saying, Son, go work today in my vineyard.
Chapter 21.:27: He answered and said, I will not; but afterward he repented and went.
Chapter 21.:28: And he came to the second and said likewise. And he answered and said, I will serve; and went not.
Chapter 21.:29: Whether of these twain did the will of their father?
Chapter 21.:30: They said unto him, The first.
Chapter 21.:31: Jesus said unto them, Verily, I say unto you that the publicans and harlots shall go into the kingdom of God before you.
Chapter 21.:32: For John came unto you in the way of righteousness and bare record of me, and ye believed him not; but the publicans and the harlots believed him; and ye, afterward, when ye had seen me, repented not, that ye might believe him.
Chapter 21.:33: For he that believed not John concerning me cannot believe me, except he first repent.
Chapter 21.:34: And except ye repent, the preaching of John shall condemn you in the day of judgment. And again, hear another parable; for unto you that believe not, I speak in parables, that your unrighteousness may be rewarded unto you.
Chapter 21.:35: Behold, there was a certain householder, who planted a vineyard, and hedged it round about, and digged a winepress in it, and built a tower, and let it out to husbandmen, and went into a far country.
Chapter 21.:36: And when the time of the fruit drew near, he sent his servants to the husbandmen, that they might receive the fruits of it.
Chapter 21.:37: And the husbandmen took his servants, and beat one, and killed another, and stoned another.
Chapter 21.:38: Again, he sent other servants, more than the first; and they did unto them likewise.
Chapter 21.:39: But last of all, he sent unto them his son, saying, They will reverence my son.
Chapter 21.:40: But when the husbandmen saw the son, they said among themselves, This is the heir; come, let us kill him, and let us seize on his inheritance.
Chapter 21.:41: And they caught him, and cast him out of the vineyard, and slew him.
Chapter 21.:42: And Jesus said unto them, When the Lord, therefore, of the vineyard cometh, what will he do unto those husbandmen?
Chapter 21.:43: They said unto him, He will destroy those miserable, wicked men and will let out the vineyard unto other husbandmen, who shall render him the fruits in their seasons.
Chapter 21.:44: Jesus said unto them, Did ye never read in the scriptures, The stone which the builders rejected, the same is become the head of the corner; this is the Lord's doings, and it is marvelous in our eyes.
Chapter 21.:45: Therefore, say I unto you, The kingdom of God shall be taken from you and given to a nation bringing forth the fruits thereof.
Chapter 21.:46: For whosoever shall fall on this stone shall be broken; but on whomsoever it shall fall, it will grind him to powder.
Chapter 21.:47: And when the chief priests and Pharisees had heard his parables, they perceived that he spoke of them.
Chapter 21.:48: And they said among themselves, Shall this man think that he alone can spoil this great kingdom? And they were angry with him.
Chapter 21.:49: But when they sought to lay hands on him, they feared the multitude because they learned that the multitude took him for a prophet.
Chapter 21.:50: And now his disciples came to him; and Jesus said unto them, Marvel ye at the words of the parable which I spake unto them?
Chapter 21.:51: Verily, I say unto you, I am the stone, and those wicked ones reject me.
Chapter 21.:52: I am the head of the corner. These Jews shall fall upon me and shall be broken.
Chapter 21.:53: And the kingdom of God shall be taken from them and shall be given to a nation bringing forth the fruits thereof (meaning the Gentiles).
Chapter 21.:54: Wherefore, on whomsoever this stone shall fall, it shall grind him to powder.
Chapter 21.:55: And when the Lord, therefore, of the vineyard cometh, he will destroy those miserable, wicked men, and will let again his vineyard unto other husbandmen, even in the last days, who shall render him the fruits in their seasons.
Chapter 21.:56: And then understood they the parable which he spake unto them, that the Gentiles should be destroyed also, when the Lord should descend out of heaven to reign in his vineyard, which is the earth and the inhabitants thereof.

Chapter 22.:1: And Jesus answered the people again, and spake unto them in parables, and said,
Chapter 22.:2: The kingdom of heaven is like unto a certain king, who made a marriage for his son.
Chapter 22.:3: And when the marriage was ready, he sent forth his servants to call them that were bidden to the wedding; and they would not come.
Chapter 22.:4: Again he sent forth other servants, saying, Tell them that are bidden, Behold, I have prepared my oxen, and my fatlings have been killed, and my dinner is ready, and all things are prepared; therefore, come unto the marriage.
Chapter 22.:5: But they made light of the servants and went their ways, one to his farm, another to his merchandise;
Chapter 22.:6: And the remnant took his servants, and entreated them spitefully, and slew them.
Chapter 22.:7: But when the king heard that his servants were dead, he was wroth; and he sent forth his armies, and destroyed those murderers, and burned up their city.
Chapter 22.:8: Then said he to his servants, The wedding is ready; but they who were bidden were not worthy.
Chapter 22.:9: Go ye, therefore, into the highways, and as many as ye shall find, bid to the marriage.
Chapter 22.:10: So those servants went out into the highways and gathered together all, as many as they found, both bad and good; and the wedding was furnished with guests.
Chapter 22.:11: But when the king came in to see the guests, he saw there a man who had not a wedding garment.
Chapter 22.:12: And he said unto him, Friend, how camest thou in hither, not having a wedding garment? And he was speechless.
Chapter 22.:13: Then said the king unto his servants, Bind him hand and foot, and take and cast him away into outer darkness; there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Chapter 22.:14: For many are called, but few chosen; wherefore, all do not have on the wedding garment.
Chapter 22.:15: Then went the Pharisees and took counsel how they might entangle him in talk.
Chapter 22.:16: And they sent out unto him their disciples with the Herodians, saying, Master, we know that thou art true, and teachest the way of God in truth, neither carest thou for any; for thou regardest not the person of men.
Chapter 22.:17: Tell us, therefore, What thinkest thou? Is it lawful to give tribute unto Caesar, or not?
Chapter 22.:18: But Jesus perceived their wickedness and said, Ye hypocrites! Why tempt ye me? Show me the tribute money.
Chapter 22.:19: And they brought unto him a penny.
Chapter 22.:20: He said unto them, Whose image is this, and superscription?
Chapter 22.:21: They said unto him, Caesar's. Then said he unto them, Render, therefore, unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things which are God's.
Chapter 22.:22: And when they had heard him say these words, they marveled, and left him, and went their way.
Chapter 22.:23: The same day came the Sadducees to him, who say that there is no resurrection, and asked him, saying, Master, Moses said, If a man die, having no children, his brother shall marry his wife and raise up seed unto his brother.
Chapter 22.:24: Now there were with us, seven brethren; and the first, when he had married a wife, deceased; and, having no issue, he left his wife unto his brother.
Chapter 22.:25: Likewise the second also, and the third, and even unto the seventh.
Chapter 22.:26: And last of all the woman died also.
Chapter 22.:27: Therefore, in the resurrection, whose wife shall she be of the seven? For they all had her.
Chapter 22.:28: Jesus answered and said unto them, Ye do err, not knowing the scriptures nor the power of God.
Chapter 22.:29: For in the resurrection, they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are as the angels of God in heaven.
Chapter 22.:30: But as touching the resurrection of the dead, have ye not read that which was spoken unto you of God, saying,
Chapter 22.:31: I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living.
Chapter 22.:32: And when the multitude heard him, they were astonished at his doctrine.
Chapter 22.:33: But when the Pharisees heard that he had put the Sadducees to silence, they were gathered together.
Chapter 22.:34: Then one of them, a lawyer, tempting him, asked, saying,
Chapter 22.:35: Master, which is the great commandment in the law?
Chapter 22.:36: Jesus said unto him, Thou shalt love the Lord, thy God, with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind.
Chapter 22.:37: This is the first and great commandment.
Chapter 22.:38: And the second is like unto it: Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself.
Chapter 22.:39: On these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets.
Chapter 22.:40: While the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus asked them, saying, What think ye of Christ? Whose son is he?
Chapter 22.:41: They said unto him, The Son of David.
Chapter 22.:42: He said unto them, How then doth David in spirit call him Lord, saying, The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand till I make thine enemies thy footstool?
Chapter 22.:43: If David then called him Lord, how is he his son?
Chapter 22.:44: And no man was able to answer him a word, neither durst any man from that day forth ask him any more questions.

Chapter 23.Header: Christ upbraids scribes for their hypocrisy--Weeps over Jerusalem
Chapter 23.:1: Then spake Jesus to the multitude and to his disciples, saying, The scribes and the Pharisees sit in Moses' seat.
Chapter 23.:2: All, therefore, whatsoever they bid you observe, they will make you observe and do; for they are ministers of the law, and they make themselves your judges. But do not ye after their works; for they say, and do not.
Chapter 23.:3: For they bind heavy burdens and lay on men's shoulders, and they are grievous to be borne; but they will not move them with one of their fingers.
Chapter 23.:4: And all their works they do to be seen of men. They make broad their phylacteries, and enlarge the borders of their garments, and love the uppermost rooms at feasts, and the chief seats in the synagogues, and greetings in the markets, and to be called of men, Rabbi, Rabbi (which is master).
Chapter 23.:5: But be not ye called Rabbi; for one is your master, which is Christ; and all ye are brethren.
Chapter 23.:6: And call no one your creator upon the earth, or your heavenly Father; for one is your creator and heavenly Father, even he who is in heaven.
Chapter 23.:7: Neither be ye called Master; for one is your master, even he whom your heavenly Father sent, which is Christ; for he hath sent him among you that ye might have life.
Chapter 23.:8: But he that is greatest among you shall be your servant.
Chapter 23.:9: And whosoever shall exalt himself shall be abased of him; and he that shall humble himself shall be exalted of him.
Chapter 23.:10: But woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For ye shut up the kingdom of heaven against men; for ye neither go in yourselves, neither suffer ye them that are entering to go in.
Chapter 23.:11: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees! For ye are hypocrites! Ye devour widows' houses, and for a pretense make long prayers; therefore, ye shall receive the greater punishment.
Chapter 23.:12: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For ye compass sea and land to make one proselyte; and when he is made, you make him twofold more the child of hell than he was before, like unto yourselves.
Chapter 23.:13: Woe unto you, blind guides, who say, Whosoever shall swear by the temple, it is nothing; but whosoever shall swear by the gold of the temple, he committeth sin and is a debtor.
Chapter 23.:14: You are fools and blind; for which is the greater, the gold or the temple that sanctifieth the gold?
Chapter 23.:15: And ye say, Whosoever sweareth by the altar, it is nothing; but whosoever sweareth by the gift that is upon it, he is guilty.
Chapter 23.:16: O fools and blind! For which is the greater, the gift or the altar that sanctifieth the gift?
Chapter 23.:17: Verily, I say unto you, Whoso, therefore, sweareth by it, sweareth by the altar and by all things thereon.
Chapter 23.:18: And whoso shall swear by the temple, sweareth by it and by him who dwelleth therein.
Chapter 23.:19: And he that shall swear by heaven, sweareth by the throne of God and by him who sitteth thereon.
Chapter 23.:20: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you pay tithe of mint, and anise, and cummin, and have omitted the weightier things of the law: judgment, mercy, and faith; these ought ye to have done and not to leave the other undone.
Chapter 23.:21: You blind guides, who strain at a gnat and swallow a camel, who make yourselves appear unto men that ye would not commit the least sin; and yet you, yourselves, transgress the whole law.
Chapter 23.:22: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you make clean the outside of the cup and of the platter; but within they are full of extortion and excess.
Chapter 23.:23: You blind Pharisees! Cleanse first the cup and platter within, that the outside of them may be clean also.
Chapter 23.:24: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For ye are like unto whited sepulchers, which indeed appear beautiful outwardly, but are within full of the bones of the dead and of all uncleanness.
Chapter 23.:25: Even so, you also outwardly appear righteous unto men, but within you are full of hypocrisy and iniquity.
Chapter 23.:26: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because you build the tombs of the prophets, and garnish the sepulchers of the righteous,
Chapter 23.:27: And say, If we had been in the days of our fathers, we would not have been partakers with them in the blood of the prophets,
Chapter 23.:28: Wherefore, you are witnesses unto yourselves of your own wickedness; and you are the children of them who killed the prophets,
Chapter 23.:29: And will fill up the measure then of your fathers; for you, yourselves, kill the prophets like unto your fathers.
Chapter 23.:30: You serpents and generation of vipers! How can you escape the damnation of hell?
Chapter 23.:31: Wherefore, behold, I send unto you prophets, and wise men, and scribes; and of them you shall kill and crucify; and of them you shall scourge in your synagogues and persecute from city to city;
Chapter 23.:32: That upon you may come all the righteous blood shed upon the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel, unto the blood of Zacharias, son of Barachias, whom ye slew between the temple and the altar.
Chapter 23.:33: Verily, I say unto you, All these things shall come upon this generation.
Chapter 23.:34: You bear testimony against your fathers when you, yourselves, are partakers of the same wickedness.
Chapter 23.:35: Behold your fathers did it through ignorance, but you do not; wherefore, their sins shall be upon your heads.
Chapter 23.:36: Then Jesus began to weep over Jerusalem, saying,
Chapter 23.:37: O Jerusalem! Jerusalem! You who will kill the prophets and will stone them who are sent unto you, how often would I have gathered your children together, even as a hen gathers her chickens under her wings; and ye would not.
Chapter 23.:38: Behold, your house is left unto you desolate!
Chapter 23.:39: For I say unto you that you shall not see me henceforth and know that I am he of whom it is written by the prophets, until ye shall say,
Chapter 23.:40: Blessed is he who cometh in the name of the Lord, in the clouds of heaven, and all the holy angels with him.
Chapter 23.:41: Then understood his disciples that he should come again on the earth after that he was glorified and crowned on the right hand of God.

Chapter 24.Header: Christ foretells destruction of Jerusalem and the end of the wicked
Chapter 24.:1: And Jesus went out and departed from the temple; and his disciples came to him for to hear him, saying, Master, show us concerning the buildings of the temple; as thou hast said, They shall be thrown down and left unto you desolate.
Chapter 24.:2: And Jesus said unto them, See ye not all these things? And do you not understand them? Verily, I say unto you, There shall not be left here upon this temple one stone upon another that shall not be thrown down.
Chapter 24.:3: And Jesus left them and went upon the mount of Olives.
Chapter 24.:4: And as he sat upon the mount of Olives, the disciples came unto him privately, saying, Tell us, when shall these things be which thou hast said concerning the destruction of the temple, and the Jews; and what is the sign of thy coming and of the end of the world (or the destruction of the wicked, which is the end of the world)?
Chapter 24.:5: And Jesus answered and said unto them, Take heed that no man deceive you.
Chapter 24.:6: For many shall come in my name, saying, I am Christ, and shall deceive many.
Chapter 24.:7: Then shall they deliver you up to be afflicted and shall kill you; and you shall be hated of all nations for my name's sake.
Chapter 24.:8: And then shall many be offended, and shall betray one another, and shall hate one another.
Chapter 24.:9: And many false prophets shall arise and shall deceive many.
Chapter 24.:10: And because iniquity shall abound, the love of many shall wax cold.
Chapter 24.:11: But he that remaineth steadfast and is not overcome, the same shall be saved.
Chapter 24.:12: When you, therefore, shall see the abomination of desolation spoken of by Daniel the prophet, concerning the destruction of Jerusalem, then you shall stand in the holy place. (Whoso readeth let him understand.)
Chapter 24.:13: Then let them who are in Judea flee into the mountains.
Chapter 24.:14: Let him who is on the housetop flee and not return to take anything out of his house.
Chapter 24.:15: Neither let him who is in the field return back to take his clothes.
Chapter 24.:16: And woe unto them that are with child and unto them that give suck in those days!
Chapter 24.:17: Therefore, pray ye the Lord that your flight be not in the winter, neither on the Sabbath day.
Chapter 24.:18: For then, in those days, shall be great tribulations on the Jews and upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem, such as was not before sent upon Israel, of God, since the beginning of their kingdom until this time, no, nor ever shall be sent again upon Israel.
Chapter 24.:19: All things which have befallen them are only the beginning of the sorrows which shall come upon them; and except those days should be shortened, there should none of their flesh be saved.
Chapter 24.:20: But for the elect's sake, according to the covenant, those days shall be shortened.
Chapter 24.:21: Behold, these things I have spoken unto you concerning the Jews.
Chapter 24.:22: And again, after the tribulation of those days which shall come upon Jerusalem, if any man shall say unto you, Lo! Here is Christ, or there, believe him not.
Chapter 24.:23: For in those days, there shall also arise false Christs and false prophets and shall show great signs and wonders, insomuch that, if possible, they shall deceive the very elect, who are the elect according to the covenant.
Chapter 24.:24: Behold, I speak these things unto you for the elect's sake.
Chapter 24.:25: And you also shall hear of wars and rumors of wars; see that ye be not troubled; for all I have told you must come to pass. But the end is not yet.
Chapter 24.:26: Behold, I have told you before, Wherefore, if they shall say unto you, Behold, he is in the desert, go not forth, or, Behold, he is in the secret chambers, believe it not.
Chapter 24.:27: For as the light of the morning cometh out of the east, and shineth even unto the west, and covereth the whole earth, so shall also the coming of the Son of Man be.
Chapter 24.:28: And now I show unto you a parable: Behold, wheresoever the carcass is, there will the eagles be gathered together; so likewise shall mine elect be gathered from the four quarters of the earth.
Chapter 24.:29: And they shall hear of wars and rumors of wars. Behold, I speak unto you for mine elect's sake.
Chapter 24.:30: For nation shall rise against nation and kingdom against kingdom; there shall be famine, and pestilences, and earthquakes in divers places.
Chapter 24.:31: And again, because iniquity shall abound, the love of men shall wax cold; but he that shall not be overcome, the same shall be saved.
Chapter 24.:32: And again, this gospel of the kingdom shall be preached in all the world for a witness unto all nations; and then shall the end come, or the destruction of the wicked.
Chapter 24.:33: And again, shall the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, be fulfilled.
Chapter 24.:34: And immediately after the tribulation of those days, the sun shall be darkened, and the moon shall not give her light, and the stars shall fall from heaven, and the powers of heaven shall be shaken.
Chapter 24.:35: Verily, I say unto you, This generation, in which these things shall be shown forth, shall not pass away until all I have told you shall be fulfilled.
Chapter 24.:36: Although the days will come that heaven and earth shall pass away, yet my word shall not pass away; but all shall be fulfilled.
Chapter 24.:37: And as I said before, After the tribulation of those days, and the powers of the heavens shall be shaken, then shall appear the sign of the Son of Man in heaven; and then shall all the tribes of the earth mourn.
Chapter 24.:38: And they shall see the Son of Man coming in the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.
Chapter 24.:39: And whoso treasureth up my words shall not be deceived.
Chapter 24.:40: For the Son of Man shall come, and he shall send his angels before him with the great sound of a trumpet; and they shall gather together the remainder of his elect from the four winds, from one end of heaven to the other.
Chapter 24.:41: Now learn a parable of the fig tree: When its branches are yet tender and it begins to put forth leaves, you know that summer is nigh at hand.
Chapter 24.:42: So likewise mine elect, when they shall see all these things, they shall know that he is near, even at the doors.
Chapter 24.:43: But of that day and hour no one knoweth; no, not the angels of God in heaven, but my Father only.
Chapter 24.:44: But as it was in the days of Noah, so it shall be also at the coming of the Son of Man.
Chapter 24.:45: For it shall be with them as it was in the days which were before the flood; for until the day that Noah entered into the ark, they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, and knew not until the flood came and took them all away; so shall also the coming of the Son of Man be.
Chapter 24.:46: Then shall be fulfilled that which is written, that in the last days,
Chapter 24.:47: Two shall be in the field; the one shall be taken and the other left.
Chapter 24.:48: Two shall be grinding at the mill; the one taken and the other left.
Chapter 24.:49: And what I say unto one, I say unto all men: Watch, therefore, for you know not at what hour your Lord doth come.
Chapter 24.:50: But know this, if the good man of the house had known in what watch the thief would come, he would have watched and would not have suffered his house to have been broken up, but would have been ready.
Chapter 24.:51: Therefore, be ye also ready; for in such an hour as ye think not, the Son of Man cometh.
Chapter 24.:52: Who then is a faithful and wise servant, whom his Lord hath made ruler over his household, to give them meat in due season?
Chapter 24.:53: Blessed is that servant, whom his Lord when he cometh shall find so doing;
Chapter 24.:54: And verily, I say unto you, He shall make him ruler over all his goods.
Chapter 24.:55: But if that evil servant shall say in his heart, My Lord delayeth his coming, and shall begin to smite his fellow servants, and to eat and drink with the drunken, the Lord of that servant shall come in a day when he looketh not for him, and in an hour that he is not aware of, and shall cut him asunder, and shall appoint him his portion with the hypocrites; there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Chapter 24.:56: And thus cometh the end of the wicked according to the prophecy of Moses, saying, They should be cut off from among the people. But the end of the earth is not yet, but by and by.

Chapter 25.Header: Parable of the ten virgins--The talents--The judgment
Chapter 25.:1: And then, at that day before the Son of Man comes, the kingdom of heaven shall be likened unto ten virgins, who took their lamps and went forth to meet the bridegroom.
Chapter 25.:2: And five of them were wise, and five of them were foolish.
Chapter 25.:3: They that were foolish took their lamps and took no oil with them; but the wise took oil in their vessels with their lamps.
Chapter 25.:4: While the bridegroom tarried, they all slumbered and slept.
Chapter 25.:5: And at midnight there was a cry made: Behold, the bridegroom cometh! Go ye out to meet him!
Chapter 25.:6: Then all those virgins arose and trimmed their lamps.
Chapter 25.:7: And the foolish said unto the wise, Give us of your oil; for our lamps are gone out.
Chapter 25.:8: But the wise answered, saying, Lest there be not enough for us and you, go you rather to them that sell, and buy for yourselves.
Chapter 25.:9: And while they went to buy, the bridegroom came; and they that were ready went in with him to the marriage, and the door was shut.
Chapter 25.:10: Afterward came also the other virgins, saying, Lord, Lord, open unto us.
Chapter 25.:11: But he answered and said, Verily, I say unto you, You know me not.
Chapter 25.:12: Watch, therefore, for you know neither the day nor the hour wherein the Son of Man cometh.
Chapter 25.:13: Now I will liken these things unto a parable.
Chapter 25.:14: For it is like as a man traveling into a far country, who called his own servants and delivered unto them his goods.
Chapter 25.:15: And unto one he gave five talents, to another two, and to another one, to every man according to his several ability, and straightway went on his journey.
Chapter 25.:16: Then he that had received the five talents went, and traded with the same, and gained other five talents.
Chapter 25.:17: And, likewise, he who received two talents, he also gained other two.
Chapter 25.:18: But he who had received one went, and digged in the earth, and hid his lord's money.
Chapter 25.:19: After a long time, the lord of those servants cometh and reckoneth with them.
Chapter 25.:20: And so he that had received the five talents came and brought other five talents, saying, Lord, thou deliveredst unto me five talents; behold, I have gained, besides them, five talents more.
Chapter 25.:21: His lord said unto him, Well done, good and faithful servant; thou hast been faithful over a few things; I will make thee ruler over many things; enter thou into the joy of thy lord.
Chapter 25.:22: He also that had received two talents came and said, Lord, thou deliveredst unto me two talents; behold, I have gained two talents besides them.
Chapter 25.:23: His lord said unto him, Well done, good and faithful servant; thou hast been faithful over a few things; I will make thee ruler over many things; enter thou into the joy of thy lord.
Chapter 25.:24: Then he who had received the one talent came and said, Lord, I knew thee, that thou art a hard man, reaping where thou hast not sown and gathering where thou hast not scattered.
Chapter 25.:25: And I was afraid, and went, and hid thy talent in the earth; and lo, here is thy talent; take it from me as thou hast from thine other servants, for it is thine.
Chapter 25.:26: His lord answered and said unto him, O wicked and slothful servant, thou knewest that I reap where I sowed not and gather where I have not scattered.
Chapter 25.:27: Having known this, therefore, thou oughtest to have put my money to the exchangers; and at my coming, I should have received mine own with usury.
Chapter 25.:28: I will take, therefore, the talent from you and give it unto him who hath ten talents.
Chapter 25.:29: For unto everyone who hath obtained other talents shall be given, and he shall have in abundance.
Chapter 25.:30: But from him that hath not obtained other talents shall be taken away even that which he hath received.
Chapter 25.:31: And his lord shall say unto his servants, Cast ye the unprofitable servant into outer darkness; there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Chapter 25.:32: When the Son of Man shall come in his glory, and all the holy angels with him, then he shall sit upon the throne of his glory;
Chapter 25.:33: And before him shall be gathered all nations; and he shall separate them one from another, as a shepherd divideth sheep from the goats: the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on his left.
Chapter 25.:34: And he shall sit upon his throne, and the twelve apostles with him.
Chapter 25.:35: Then shall the King say unto them on his right hand, Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world.
Chapter 25.:36: For I was an hungered, and ye gave me meat; I was thirsty, and ye gave me drink; I was a stranger, and ye took me in; naked, and ye clothed me;
Chapter 25.:37: I was sick, and ye visited me; I was in prison, and ye came unto me.
Chapter 25.:38: Then shall the righteous answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thee an hungered and fed thee, or thirsty and gave thee drink?
Chapter 25.:39: When saw we thee a stranger and took thee in, or naked and clothed thee?
Chapter 25.:40: Or when saw we thee sick, or in prison, and came unto thee?
Chapter 25.:41: And the King shall answer and say unto them, Verily, I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these my brethren, ye have done it unto me.
Chapter 25.:42: Then shall he say also unto them on the left hand, Depart from me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire prepared for the devil and his angels.
Chapter 25.:43: For I was an hungered, and ye gave me no meat; I was thirsty, and ye gave me no drink;
Chapter 25.:44: I was a stranger, and ye took me not in; naked, and ye clothed me not; sick, and in prison, and ye visited me not.
Chapter 25.:45: Then shall they also answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thee an hungered, or athirst, or a stranger, or naked, or sick, or in prison, and did not minister unto thee?
Chapter 25.:46: Then shall he answer them, saying, Verily, I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these my brethren, ye did it not unto me.
Chapter 25.:47: And these shall go away into everlasting punishment, but the righteous into life eternal.

Chapter 26.:1: And it came to pass, when Jesus had finished all these sayings, he said unto his disciples,
Chapter 26.:2: Ye know that after two days is the passover, and then the Son of Man is betrayed to be crucified.
Chapter 26.:3: Then assembled together the chief priests, and the scribes, and the elders of the people unto the palace of the high priest, who was called Caiaphas, and consulted that they might take Jesus by subtlety and kill him.
Chapter 26.:4: But they said, Not on the feast day, lest there be an uproar among the people.
Chapter 26.:5: Now when Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper, there came unto him a woman having an alabaster box of very precious ointment, and poured it on his head as he sat in the house.
Chapter 26.:6: But when some saw this, they had indignation, saying, Unto what purpose is this waste? For this ointment might have been sold for much and given to the poor.
Chapter 26.:7: When they had said thus, Jesus understood them; and he said unto them, Why trouble ye the woman? For she hath wrought a good work upon me.
Chapter 26.:8: For ye have the poor always with you; but me ye have not always.
Chapter 26.:9: For she hath poured this ointment on my body for my burial.
Chapter 26.:10: And in this thing that she hath done, she shall be blessed; for verily, I say unto you, Wheresoever this gospel shall be preached in the whole world, this thing that this woman hath done shall also be told for a memorial of her.
Chapter 26.:11: Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went unto the chief priests and said, What will ye give me, and I will deliver him unto you? And they covenanted with him for thirty pieces of silver.
Chapter 26.:12: And from that time he sought opportunity to betray Jesus.
Chapter 26.:13: Now on the first day of the feast of unleavened bread, the disciples came unto Jesus, saying unto him, Where wilt thou that we prepare for thee to eat the passover?
Chapter 26.:14: And he said, Go into the city to such a man and say unto him, The Master saith, My time is at hand; I will keep the passover at thy house with my disciples.
Chapter 26.:15: And the disciples did as Jesus appointed them; and they made ready the passover.
Chapter 26.:16: Now when the evening was come, he sat down with the twelve.
Chapter 26.:17: And as they did eat, he said, Verily, I say unto you that one of you shall betray me.
Chapter 26.:18: And they were exceeding sorrowful, and began every one of them to say unto him, Lord, is it I?
Chapter 26.:19: And he answered and said, He that dippeth his hand with me in the dish, the same shall betray me.
Chapter 26.:20: But the Son of Man goeth as it is written of him; but woe unto that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It had been good for that man if he had not been born.
Chapter 26.:21: Then Judas, who betrayed him, answered and said, Master, is it I? He said unto him, Thou hast said.
Chapter 26.:22: And as they were eating, Jesus took bread and brake it, and blessed it, and gave to his disciples, and said, Take, eat; this is in remembrance of my body which I give a ransom for you.
Chapter 26.:23: And he took the cup, and gave thanks, and gave it to them, saying, Drink ye all of it.
Chapter 26.:24: For this is in remembrance of my blood of the new testament, which is shed for as many as shall believe on my name, for the remission of their sins.
Chapter 26.:25: And I give unto you a commandment that ye shall observe to do the things which ye have seen me do and bear record of me even unto the end.
Chapter 26.:26: But I say unto you, I will not drink henceforth of this fruit of the vine until that day when I shall come and drink it anew with you in my Father's kingdom.
Chapter 26.:27: And when they had sung a hymn, they went out into the mount of Olives.
Chapter 26.:28: Then said Jesus unto them, All ye shall be offended because of me this night; for it is written, I will smite the Shepherd, and the sheep of the flock shall be scattered abroad.
Chapter 26.:29: But after I am risen again, I will go before you into Galilee.
Chapter 26.:30: Peter answered and said unto him, Though all men shall be offended because of thee, I will never be offended.
Chapter 26.:31: Jesus said unto him, Verily, I say unto thee that this night, before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice.
Chapter 26.:32: Peter said unto him, Though I should die with thee, yet will I not deny thee. Likewise also said all the disciples.
Chapter 26.:33: Then cometh Jesus with them unto a place called Gethsemane and said unto the disciples, Sit ye here while I go yonder and pray.
Chapter 26.:34: And he took with him Peter and the two sons of Zebedee and began to be sorrowful and very heavy.
Chapter 26.:35: Then said he unto them, My soul is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death; tarry ye here and watch with me.
Chapter 26.:36: And he went a little farther, and fell on his face, and prayed, saying, O my Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me; nevertheless, not as I will, but as thou wilt.
Chapter 26.:37: And he cometh unto the disciples, and findeth them asleep, and saith unto Peter, What, could ye not watch with me one hour?
Chapter 26.:38: Watch and pray that ye enter not into temptation; the spirit indeed is willing; but the flesh is weak.
Chapter 26.:39: He went away again the second time and prayed, saying, O my Father, if this cup may not pass away from me, except I drink it, thy will be done.
Chapter 26.:40: And he came and found them asleep again; for their eyes were heavy.
Chapter 26.:41: And he left them, and went away again, and prayed the third time, saying the same words.
Chapter 26.:42: Then cometh he to his disciples and saith unto them, Sleep on now and take rest. Behold, the hour is at hand, and the Son of Man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.
Chapter 26.:43: And after they had slept, he said unto them, Arise, and let us be going. Behold, he is at hand that doth betray me.
Chapter 26.:44: And while he yet spake, lo, Judas, one of the twelve, came, and with him a great multitude with swords and staves, from the chief priests and elders of the people.
Chapter 26.:45: Now he that betrayed him gave them a sign, saying, Whomsoever I shall kiss, that same is he; hold him fast.
Chapter 26.:46: And forthwith he came to Jesus and said, Hail, Master! and kissed him.
Chapter 26.:47: And Jesus said unto him, Judas, wherefore art thou come to betray me with a kiss?
Chapter 26.:48: Then came they, and laid hands on Jesus, and took him.
Chapter 26.:49: And behold, one of them which were with Jesus stretched out his hand, and drew his sword, and struck a servant of the high priest, and smote off his ear.
Chapter 26.:50: Then said Jesus unto him, Put up again thy sword into its place; for all they that take the sword shall perish with the sword.
Chapter 26.:51: Thinkest thou that I cannot now pray to my Father, and he shall presently give me more than twelve legions of angels?
Chapter 26.:52: But how then shall the scriptures be fulfilled, that thus it must be?
Chapter 26.:53: In that same hour said Jesus unto the multitudes, Are ye come out as against a thief, with swords and staves, for to take me? I sat daily with you in the temple, teaching, and ye laid no hold on me.
Chapter 26.:54: But all this was done that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled.
Chapter 26.:55: Then all the disciples forsook him and fled.
Chapter 26.:56: And they that had laid hold on Jesus led him away to Caiaphas the high priest, where the scribes and the elders were assembled.
Chapter 26.:57: But Peter followed him afar off unto the high priest's palace, and went in, and sat with the servants to see the end.
Chapter 26.:58: Now the chief priests, and elders, and all the council sought false witness against Jesus, to put him to death, but found none.
Chapter 26.:59: Yea, though many false witnesses came, they found none that could accuse him.
Chapter 26.:60: At the last came two false witnesses and said, This man said, I am able to destroy the temple of God and to build it in three days.
Chapter 26.:61: And the high priest arose and said unto him, Answerest thou nothing? Knowest thou what these witness against thee?
Chapter 26.:63: And the high priest answered and said unto him,
Chapter 26.:64: I adjure thee, by the living God, that thou tell us whether thou be the Christ, the Son of God.
Chapter 26.:65: Jesus said unto him, Thou hast said. Nevertheless, I say unto you, Hereafter shall ye see the Son of Man sitting on the right hand of power and coming in the clouds of heaven.
Chapter 26.:66: Then the high priest rent his clothes, saying, He hath spoken blasphemy; what further need have we of witnesses? Behold, now ye have heard his blasphemy. What think ye?
Chapter 26.:67: They answered and said, He is guilty and worthy of death.
Chapter 26.:68: Then did they spit in his face and buffet him; and others smote him with the palms of their hands, saying, Prophesy unto us, thou Christ. Who is it that smote thee?
Chapter 26.:69: Now Peter sat without in the palace; and a damsel came unto him, saying, Thou also wast with Jesus of Galilee.
Chapter 26.:70: But he denied before them all, saying, I know not what thou sayest.
Chapter 26.:71: And when he was gone out into the porch, another saw him and said unto them that were there, This man was also with Jesus of Nazareth.
Chapter 26.:72: And again he denied with an oath, saying, I do not know the man.
Chapter 26.:73: And after a while, came they that stood by and said to Peter, Surely thou also art one of them, for thy speech betrayeth thee.
Chapter 26.:74: Then began he to curse and to swear, saying, I know not the man.
Chapter 26.:76: And Peter remembered the words of Jesus, which he said unto him, Before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice. And he went out and wept bitterly.

Chapter 27.:1: When the morning was come, all the chief priests and elders of the people took counsel against Jesus, to put him to death.
Chapter 27.:2: And when they had bound him, they led him away and delivered him to Pontius Pilate, the governor.
Chapter 27.:3: Then Judas, who had betrayed him, when he saw that he was condemned, repented himself and brought again the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders,
Chapter 27.:4: Saying, I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood.
Chapter 27.:5: And they said unto him, What is that to us? See thou to it; thy sins be upon thee.
Chapter 27.:6: And he cast down the pieces of silver in the temple, and departed, and went, and hanged himself on a tree. And straightway he fell down, and his bowels gushed out, and he died.
Chapter 27.:7: And the chief priests took the silver pieces and said, It is not lawful for to put them in the treasury because it is the price of blood.
Chapter 27.:8: And they took counsel and bought with them the potter's field to bury strangers in. Wherefore, that field was called the field of blood unto this day.
Chapter 27.:9: Then was fulfilled that which was spoken by Jeremy, the prophet, saying, And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of him that was valued, whom they of the children of Israel did value.
Chapter 27.:10: And, therefore, they took the pieces of silver and gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord appointed by the mouth of Jeremy.
Chapter 27.:11: And Jesus stood before the governor; and the governor asked him, saying, Art thou the King of the Jews?
Chapter 27.:12: And Jesus said unto him, Thou sayest truly; for thus it is written of me.
Chapter 27.:13: And when he was accused of the chief priests and elders, he answered nothing.
Chapter 27.:14: Then saith Pilate unto him, Hearest thou not how many things they witness against thee?
Chapter 27.:15: And he answered him not to his questions; yea, never a word, insomuch that the governor marveled greatly.
Chapter 27.:16: Now at the feast the governor was wont to release unto the people a prisoner, whom they would.
Chapter 27.:17: And they had then a notable prisoner called Barabbas.
Chapter 27.:18: Therefore, when they were gathered together, Pilate said unto them, Whom will ye that I release unto you? Barabbas or Jesus, which is called Christ?
Chapter 27.:19: For he knew that for envy they had delivered him.
Chapter 27.:20: When he was set down on the judgment seat, his wife sent unto him, saying, Have thou nothing to do with that just man, for I have suffered many things this day in a vision because of him.
Chapter 27.:21: But the chief priests and elders persuaded the multitude that they should ask Barabbas and destroy Jesus.
Chapter 27.:22: And the governor said unto them, Whether of the twain will ye that I release unto you? They said, Barabbas.
Chapter 27.:23: Pilate said unto them, What shall I do with Jesus, which is called Christ?
Chapter 27.:24: And all said unto him, Let him be crucified.
Chapter 27.:25: And the governor said, Why? What evil hath he done? But they cried out the more, saying, Let him be crucified.
Chapter 27.:26: When Pilate saw that he could prevail nothing, but rather that a tumult was made, he took water and washed his hands before the multitude, saying, I am innocent of the blood of this just person; see that ye do nothing unto him.
Chapter 27.:27: Then answered all the people and said, His blood come upon us and our children.
Chapter 27.:28: Then released he Barabbas unto them; and when he had scourged Jesus, he delivered him to be crucified.
Chapter 27.:29: Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the common hall and gathered unto him the whole band.
Chapter 27.:30: And they stripped him and put on him a purple robe.
Chapter 27.:31: And when they had platted a crown of thorns, they put it upon his head, and a reed in his right hand; and they bowed the knee before him, and they mocked him, saying, Hail, King of the Jews!
Chapter 27.:32: And they spit upon him, and took the reed, and smote him on the head.
Chapter 27.:33: And after that they had mocked him, they took the robe off from him, and put his own raiment on him, and led him away to crucify him.
Chapter 27.:34: And as they came out, they found a man of Cyrene, Simon by name; him they compelled to bear his cross.
Chapter 27.:35: And when they were come unto a place called Golgotha (that is to say, a place of burial),
Chapter 27.:36: They gave him vinegar to drink mingled with gall; and when he had tasted the vinegar, he would not drink.
Chapter 27.:37: And they crucified him and parted his garments, casting lots, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, They parted my garments among them, and for my vesture they did cast lots.
Chapter 27.:38: And sitting down, they watched him there.
Chapter 27.:39: And Pilate wrote a title and put it on the cross; and the writing was,
Chapter 27.:40: JESUS OF NAZARETH, THE KING OF THE JEWS, in letters of Greek, and Latin, and Hebrew.
Chapter 27.:41: And the chief priests said unto Pilate, It should be written and set up over his head, his accusation, This is he that said he was Jesus, the King of the Jews.
Chapter 27.:42: But Pilate answered and said, What I have written, I have written; let it alone.
Chapter 27.:43: Then were there two thieves crucified with him: one on the right hand, and another on the left.
Chapter 27.:44: And they that passed by reviled him, wagging their heads and saying, Thou that destroyest the temple and buildest it again in three days, save thyself. If thou be the Son of God, come down from the cross.
Chapter 27.:45: Likewise, also the chief priests, mocking with the scribes and the elders, said, He saved others; himself he cannot save. If he be the King of Israel, let him now come down from the cross, and we will believe him.
Chapter 27.:46: He trusted in God; let him deliver him now; if he will save him, let him save him; for he said, I am the Son of God.
Chapter 27.:47: One of the thieves also, which were crucified with him, cast the same in his teeth. But the other rebuked him, saying, Dost thou not fear God, seeing thou art under the same condemnation? And this man is just and hath not sinned; and he cried unto the Lord that he would save him.
Chapter 27.:48: And the Lord said unto him, This day thou shalt be with me in paradise.
Chapter 27.:49: Now from the sixth hour there was darkness over all the land unto the ninth hour.
Chapter 27.:50: And about the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, saying, Eli, Eli, lama sabacthani? (That is to say, My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?)
Chapter 27.:51: Some of them that stood there, when they heard him, said, This man calleth for Elias.
Chapter 27.:52: And straightway one of them ran, and took a sponge, and filled it with vinegar, and put it on a reed, and gave him to drink.
Chapter 27.:53: The rest said, Let him be; let us see whether Elias will come to save him.
Chapter 27.:54: Jesus, when he had cried again with a loud voice, saying, Father, it is finished, thy will is done, yielded up the ghost.
Chapter 27.:55: And behold, the veil of the temple was rent in twain from the top to the bottom; and the earth did quake, and the rocks rent;
Chapter 27.:56: And the graves were opened; and the bodies of the saints which slept, arose, who were many,
Chapter 27.:57: And came out of the graves after his resurrection, went into the holy city, and appeared unto many.
Chapter 27.:58: Now when the centurion and they that were with him, watching Jesus, heard the earthquake and saw those things which were done, they feared greatly, saying, Truly this was the Son of God.
Chapter 27.:59: And many women were there, beholding afar off, which followed Jesus from Galilee, ministering unto him for his burial, among whom was Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James and Joses, and the mother of Zebedee's children.
Chapter 27.:60: When the evening was come, there came a rich man of Arimathea named Joseph, who also himself was Jesus' disciple; he went to Pilate and begged the body of Jesus.
Chapter 27.:61: Then Pilate commanded the body to be delivered.
Chapter 27.:62: And when Joseph had taken the body, he wrapped it in a clean linen cloth and laid it in his own new tomb, which he had hewn out in the rock; and he rolled a great stone to the door of the sepulcher and departed.
Chapter 27.:63: And there was Mary Magdalene and the other Mary, sitting over against the sepulcher.
Chapter 27.:64: Now the next day that followed the day of the preparation, the chief priests and Pharisees came together unto Pilate, saying, Sir, we remember that that deceiver said, while he was yet alive, After three days I will rise again.
Chapter 27.:65: Command, therefore, that the sepulcher be made sure until the third day, lest his disciples come by night, and steal him away, and say unto the people, He is risen from the dead; so this last imposture will be worse than the first.
Chapter 27.:66: Pilate said unto them, Ye have a watch; go your way; make it as sure as you can.
Chapter 27.:67: So they went and made the sepulcher sure, sealing the stone and setting a watch.

Chapter 28.Header: The resurrection of Christ--He sends forth his disciples to all nations
Chapter 28.:1: In the end of the Sabbath day, as it began to dawn towards the first day of the week, early in the morning came Mary Magdalene and the other Mary to see the sepulcher.
Chapter 28.:2: And behold, there had been a great earthquake; for two angels of the Lord descended from heaven, and came, and rolled back the stone from the door, and sat upon it.
Chapter 28.:3: And their countenance was like lightning, and their raiment white as snow; and for fear of them, the keepers did shake and became as though they were dead.
Chapter 28.:4: And the angels answered and said unto the women, Fear not ye; for we know that ye seek Jesus who was crucified.
Chapter 28.:5: He is not here; for he is risen, as he said. Come; see the place where the Lord lay; and go quickly and tell his disciples that he is risen from the dead; and, behold, he goeth before you into Galilee; there shall ye see him; lo, I have told you.
Chapter 28.:6: And they departed quickly from the sepulcher, with fear and great joy, and did run to bring his disciples word.
Chapter 28.:7: And as they went to tell his disciples, behold, Jesus met them, saying, All hail!
Chapter 28.:8: And they came, and held him by the feet, and worshiped him.
Chapter 28.:9: Then said Jesus unto them, Be not afraid; go tell my brethren that they go into Galilee, and there shall they see me.
Chapter 28.:10: Now when they were going, behold, some of the watch came into the city and showed unto the chief priests all the things that were done.
Chapter 28.:11: And when they were assembled with the elders and had taken counsel, they gave large money unto the soldiers,
Chapter 28.:12: Saying, Say ye, His disciples came by night and stole him while we slept.
Chapter 28.:13: And if this come to the governor's ears, we will persuade him and secure you.
Chapter 28.:14: So they took the money and did as they were taught; and this saying is commonly reported among the Jews until this day.
Chapter 28.:15: Then the eleven disciples went away into Galilee, into a mountain where Jesus had appointed them.
Chapter 28.:16: And when they saw him, they worshiped him; but some doubted.
Chapter 28.:17: And Jesus came and spake unto them, saying, All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth.
Chapter 28.:18: Go ye, therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost,
Chapter 28.:19: Teaching them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you; and, lo, I am with you always, unto the end of the world. Amen.
